More points appeared, stains, and he ate the red in them too. Skipping again, he found a time when a red door stood before him. Rather than eating it, he asked his arms to push it. They did. Korinna fell away as the door broke again, and cursed. She'd thought she wouldn't have to renew the handles for three or four mammoths. A man had somehow appeared on the snow between her and the Ivory Gate, and the Gate was a bottomless darkness rather than blooded ivory. She blinked at the scene without comprehension for several moments before finally understanding. The Gate was open! He'd come! Or was this Rahserat? He was shriveled, shrunken. She turned him over and the blood from her hands soaked immediately into his skin and disappeared. Then the snow under him did, too, and he was limned in darkness for a moment, apparently absorbing the light. He stretched and grew, withered flesh replaced with smooth skin over dense muscle. Korinna steadied herself as the hill seemed to tilt and Rahserat grew... not brighter, but everything else seemed to fade to background. But at last he become the Rahserat she dimly remembered. Then he opened his eyes. They weren't what she remembered.
TEXT.Italian: Guardiana vivente ma immortale dell'Imperatore Dormiente, e per estensione di tutti gli Eredi di Patria. Spera nell'arrivo dell'Imperatore Dormiente. Una volta Risorto, l'Imperatore permetterà a Korinna di agire come suo reggente e, essendo l'Eroina del suo popolo, di distruggere i nemici degli Eredi.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Parte 1: In una Terra Luminosa[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Parte 2: In una Terra Luminosa[\LINK][NEWLINE]Parte 3: In una Terra Luminosa[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Parte 4: In una Terra Luminosa[\LINK][NEWLINE]In una terra luminosa, sotto un cielo brillante, Korinna osservava una mandria di mammut. Indossava vestiti di pelle e pelliccia che si era fatta da sola, legati con lacci di cuoio fatti a mano, e un coltello di pietra in vita. Con i capelli sciolti al vento sorrise nel vedere i movimenti lenti di quelle enormi bestie nella pianura sottostante. Era bello vedere qualcosa muoversi, forse perfino prosperare, in questa landa ghiacciata. La cenere sotto i suoi occhi rendeva il riflesso sopportabile, ma anche cosi non fosse stato era sempre meglio dell'oscurità portata da bufere di neve che duravano settimane. Aveva conosciuto l'inverno dai morti che sognavano. Ma si aspettava di vedere anche qualcosa delle altre stagioni. No. Il mondo intero, per quanto ne sapeva, era coperto da neve e ghiaccio. Non sapeva per quanto ancora avrebbe potuto muoversi. Se il cibo e il combustibile fossero finiti... sapeva che non sarebbe morta. Non di stenti. Ma il rimanere intrappolata qui, emaciata e congelata, sarebbe come l'inferno. Si sarebbe lanciata da un dirupo prima che ciò accadesse. Tutto era iniziato in maniera cosi promettente. Una grande avventura lontano dalla madre e dal padre. Avrebbe visto il mondo dei vivi in cui era nato il padre, quando ancore ne faceva parte, e che la madre aiutava a custodire. Sua madre gli aveva detto che sebbene i sogni potevano insegnargli molto non potevano insegnargli tutto. Essi erano un'interpretazione del mondo, non quello reale. L'interpretazione di altre persone, mai la sua. Lo strano angelo furtivo, Rahserat... lei l'avrebbe aiutato ad entrare in Erebus, e poi lui gli avrebbe fatto da guida. Lei doveva obbedirgli. E lo avrebbe fatto, se mai lo avesse trovato. Ma lui dove era? Con una nuova attrezzatura da viaggio presa da una regina avventurosa, Korinna prese una delle strade del suo zio segreto per uscire dall'oltretomba. (Segreto perche lui non sapeva che lei fosse sua nipote). Entrare in Erebus fù fantastico. Vi era aria, e terra, e luce nell'oltretomba. Ovviamente. Ma non erano lo stesso tipo aria o terra o luce di Erebus. Si sentiva davvero più vicina all'Unico. O forse era solo che non si sentiva oppressa dall'ombra di Arawn. E il suo viaggio verso la Porta d'Avorio era stato una rivelazione. Fù anche lungo e arduo. La neve era la cosa peggiore. Non aveva ancora trovato il modo di fare delle racchette da neve con pelle e tendine. Non aveva ancora compreso molte cose. Il freddo era la cosa più incredibile. Il freddo sognato era mai stato tanto doloroso, pungente e pervasivo. Il freddo non era qualcosa che esisteva veramente nelle lande del sogno, vi era solo una sua pallida imitazione. Ma infine raggiunse la Porta d'Avorio. Con poco cibo ed esausta, non vedeva l'ora di rivedere Rahserat. Sia per la sua compagnia sia perché sapeva che i poteri dell'angelo sarebbero stati di di immenso aiuto nelle terre selvagge. Si arrampicò sulle colline e, seguendo le indicazioni della madre, trovò la Porta. Prese la maniglia della Porta e tirò. Se Rahserat era dall'altra parte si sarebbe aperta. Ma non si aprì. Era arrivata il giorno stabilito, pertanto aveva tirato la porta per tutto il giorno. Le sue mani venivano continuamente tagliate dagli strani barbigli sull'avorio, ma lui non arrivò. Niente angelo. Niente compagnia. Niente aiuto. Cio avvenne molto tempo fa. Lei osservava le stelle ogni volta che erano visibili. Faceva in modo di ricordarsi quali pietre stavano vicino alla porta per quando le tempeste nascondevano le stelle. Ogni anno, nel giorno stabilito, provava ad aprire la Porta, e goni anno rimaneva chiusa. Korinna si stabilì in una caverna profonda a un giorno di distanza dalla Porta. Il grande orso che ci abitava prima che arrivasse lei era diventato i suoi nuovi vestiti. Alle volte si preoccupava di aver cacciato sino all'estinzione gli animali nelle colline. Aveva tenuto traccia dei passaggi delle stelle, ma aveva evitato di tenere traccia del passare degli anni. Non voleva sapere quanto a lungo stava aspettando. Era forse stata abbandonata? Aveva evitato gli uomini per decenni. Ma poi la solitudine arrivò e realizzò che potevano essere di una certa compagnia. Mentre prima erano loro a dargli la caccia, avendo visto il fumo dei suoi fuochi, ora era lei a dare la caccia a loro. Quando trovava un cacciatore solitario lo uccideva, ma prima gli dava un messaggio per la madre. Naturalmente i primi gli dovettero anche insgenare la loro lingua. Korinna non poteva confidare in loro nel trasmettere il messaggio fino a quando non glielo ripetevano nella loro lingua. Due volte ando nei villaggi per cercare un augure. Ciò che gli venne detto gli diede speranza, anche se la donna, terrorizzata e confusa, non riusciva a dire cose sensate. Non vi erano cambiamenti degni di nota nelle terre ghiacciate, e a breve la sua vità divenne estremamente monotona. Cacciava, raccoglieva sterco di animale o, occasionalmente, legna per il fuoco. Ma non le piaceva allontanarsi dalla Porta. Componeva lunghi messaggi per la madre, e li spediva insieme a un cacciatore sfortunato ad intervalli regolari. Quando i suoi vestiti si consumavano se ne creava di nuovi, o usava quelli di chi uccideva. E osservava gli animali, non necessariamente per ucciderli. Questo è quello che faceva durante le giornate. Dormiva durante le notti e le tempeste e camminava sotto il cielo solo quando il sole splendeva. Nella sua terra luminosa i secoli passarono immutabilmente. Sino a quando, un anno, durante il giorno della Porta, entrambe le maniglie si staccarono. Le aveva tirate proprio mentre sorgeva il sole e l'intero elaborato pezzo si era staccato, aprendo un taglio profondo nella sua mano destra. Guardò l'avorio con orrore. L'occasionale giorno di sole splendente e di relativo caldo lo aveva, nel corso di un lungo lasso di tempo, corroso e fatto sgretolare. Lei non aveva mai provato rabbia, o disperazione, sino a quel giorno. Caddè preda della pazzia per un periodo di tempo nondefinito. Uccise ogni essere umano presente nel raggio di un giorno di viaggio, dicendo cose terribili a sua madre. Maledì suo padre, il falso Rahserat, e l'Unico. Smise di mangiare e rimase quasi congelata prima di venire vinta dall'appetito. Non lo sapeva, ma lei non era mai stata veramente affamata prima di allora. Si era quasi spedita alla madre, ma farlo sarebbe stato ammettere la sconfitta. Anche dopo il suo periodo nero rimase sconfortata. Forse per anni, non sapeva per certo. Ma un giorno, quando le tribù erano tornate ormai da un pò, gli vennè in mente una nuova un'idea. Forse la prima in diversi secoli. Avrebbe potuto riparare la Porta. Non sapeva quale magia la supportava, e non aveva mai pensato da dove proveniva la Porta, o chi l'avesse creata. Riteneva che fosse qualcosa fuori dal tempo, incorruttibile. Ma diversamente era per la sua forma materiale. E quella poteva ripararla. Le sue mani erano ormai esperte, dopo diverse vite dei mortali passate a creare oggetti, e vi era avorio in abbondanza. La Porta... poteva aggiustarla. E cosi fece. Con una lunga lancia dalla punta di pietra, e quanti più coltelli poteva portare facilmente cacciava ed uccideva un grande mammut ogni anno. Ricavando da esso pelliccia, avorio, e un po di cuoio, intagliando e rifinendo a lungo le spine della Porta, e facendo ciò versando anche molto sangue. Divenne parte del futile rituale annuale, il quale era l'unico evento degno di nota dei suoi immutabili giorni luminosi. Ma lui dove era? Rahserat appena lasciato l'oltretomba si sentì molto meglio di quanto si fosse sentito per secoli. Gyra, per ragioni che non riusciva a comprendere, fù un alleato inaspettato. Lei non lo aveva aiutato in maniera diretta nella sua missione, vero, ma lei l'aveva comunque aiutato a indebolire Arawn, e lei sarebbe stata quasi certamente un alleato migliore di Laroth per il suo Signore. Se non altro avrebbe potuto tornare prima e riferire di questi eventi fortuiti ad Esus. Il suo Signore avrebbe saupto cosa fare. Ma l'umore dell'angelo si dissolse appena entrò nel passaggio della Regina Nascosta diretto verso la Porta d'avorio. Non era come l'ultima volta. Questa volta era molto più buio, e attraversato da luci rosse che si aggrappavano al bordo, e solo al bordo, del campo visivo. Rahserat fece un cauto passo a sinistra, lungo il muro, e si ritrovò invece a muoversi in qualche modo verso il basso. Un altro passo, e il passaggio divenne ancora più oscuro, e ancora più verso il basso si mosse. Allora provò a risalire, a tornare indietro, ma il passaggio divenne improvvisamente completamente buoi, persino alla sua vista, e la discesa accellerò. Senza fermarsi, durando anni. Quando ebbe di nuovo cognizione di se si ritrovò strisciando su un pavimento di pietra grigia verso una grande sedia di pietra. Una luce verdastra entrava nella camera attraverso una sezione di muro che era crollata, insieme a uno strano e terribile odore. Era come quello del marciume, simile a quello del muschio di una grande bestia, o di una città. Non se ne andò mai. Non durante le settimane in cui strisciò, ne per tutto il tempo passato sulla sedia. Quando si ritrovò seduto sulla sedia, lentamente trasformandosi in pietra, la Regina Nascosta infine parlò. Realizzò he lei lo aveva osservato mentre strisciava. Lo aveva punito per il suo tradimento, per non avergli mai mandato la parola che lei cercava. Non lo aveva fatto? Pensava di averlo fatto. Aveva rotto la fiala del suo Signore non appena era arrivato. Mentre la Regina parlava di trappole e divinità, di esche, e di intrappolare l'unico, lui pensò alla fiala e al suo Signore. Il suo Signore l'aveva tradito? Aveva, la fiala, fatto qualcosa? La Regina Nascosta non poteva essere un alleato cofortevole. Il suo Signore poteva aver mentito. Questo era il suo precetto. Ma anche la Regina Nascosta poteva star mentendo. O forse il suo Signore aveva tenuto per se un segreto, anche se quello era il precetto di lei. O forse ancora lui voleva la Regina arrabbiata con Rahserat, ma non in grado di raggiungerlo. Lui, Rahserat, e separato dal pensiero del suo Signore avendo lasciato molto prima di quanto era stato pianificato. Questa strana prigione, questa bizzarra tortura, potevano essere il risultato delle sue buone intenzioni. Quando fini di rifletterci su, forse impiegando anni, la Regina Nascosta se ne era già andata via. Lei aveva detto qualcosa riguardo la fine della creazione. Era lì che si trovava? La luce era sparità per un pò, pensò, ma ora era tornata. Poteva vedere che una sedia di pietra di fronte a lui aveva degli occhi, e si stava lentamente trasformando in un uomo. Non lui. Le ombre si agitarono e ridacchiarono. I loro pensieri lo pugnalarono. I suoi vestiti si erano risvegliati dal loro sonno e se ne erano andati attraverso il buco nel muro. Li sentiva urlare mentre qualcosa li prendeva e li mangiava. Quando la luce divenne oscurità notò che la danza delle ombre rimase uguale. Comprese che non era diventata cosi oscura che l'oscurità era diventata luce. Tutto diventava sfuocato qui. I suoi pensieri in sangue, luce in oscurità, il vivente nel non vivente. E il contrario, in tutto. Il sangue in pensiero. L'oscurità in luce. Il non vivente nel vivente. Anime inviate dal falso Laroth, inviate non in un luogo, ma legate invece a lui, iniziarono ad arrivare. Lui le nascose nella pietra. Loro iniziarono le loro modifiche, ma lentamente, cosi lentamente che lui poteva piegare il tempo. Il tempo era solo un respiro dopotutto. Mentre le ombre lo prendevano in giro iniziò a comprendere. Le cose non stavano diventandone altre. No, tutte le cose erano una sola cosa qui. Unite. Se la creazione era una varietà infinita questo posto era la fine della creazione. Tutto si confondeva insieme. Perché l'Unico avrebbe potuto essere li i Rahserats non ne avevano idea. Forse quando tutto sarebbe stato una sola cosa, sarebbero diventati l'Unico? Se quello era un trucco semantico o la profonda verità la Regina forse poteva saperlo, ma loro non potevano. Con le ombre consumate, i Rahserats si riaccorparono. Era più forte ora, più forte che mai, ma diverso. Pensò che poteva essere un arcangelo ora. Si sentiva tanto potente. Ma l'arcangelo di chi? Senza le ombre predatrici lo spazio stesso crebbe. La stanza aveva ancora il buco nel muro da qualche parte, ma era perduto e piccolo ora. Il posto immenso era pieno di socurità e pietra. O di cose che erano spesso oscurità e pietra. Quella era la tendeza, almeno per ora. E ora le anime erano legione, ma ancora situate nella pietra per relativa sicurezza. Li si perdevano in sogni molto più particolari di quelli che avevano conosciuto finora. A volte l'oscurità mangiava Rahserat, e lui si contorceva e la mangiava. Forse la Regina sperava che l'Unico sarebbe giunto per salvare un povero angelo intrappolato. Ma ne dubitava. Rahserat iniziò a gironzolare col tempo. Forse più che diventare l'Unico, questo posto ne era l'antitesi. Dove l'unico era l'esistenza, ognicosa diventava ogni altra cosa era forma finale di non esistenza. Se ogni cosa esisteva come singolo, o Unico, poteva eventualmente non esserci cambiamento. E nessuna nuova creazione, in quanto tutto già esisteva. Forse l'Unico sarebbe venuto qui per distruggere il luogo. Rahserat avrebbe difeso questo luogo, questa fine della creazione? Avrebbe potuto. Ma alla fine trovò un tempo in cui l'oscurità sembrava il canto di Korinna. In realtà furono le anime nella pietra le prime a notarlo. Il canto non proveniva da dietro la breccia nel muro. Lui sapeva che non avrebbe mai potuto andare all'esterno. Non doveva. Non aveva bisogno di farlo. Il canto proveniva da un punto di rosso. Lui mangiò il rosso. Solo il colore, era uno che non aveva visto in molto tempo. Il punto rimase. Altri punti apparvero, come macchie, e mangiò il loro rosso. Muovendosi di nuovo trovò un tempo in cui vi era una porta rosso davanti a lui. Piuttosto che mangiarla chiese alle sue braccia di spingerla. E cosi fecero. Korinna cadde quando la porta si ruppe di nuovo, e imprecò. Sperava che on avrebbe dovuto rinnovare le maniglie prima di 3 o 4 mammut. Un uomo era, in uqalche modo, apparso tra lei e la Porta d'Avorio, e la Porta appariva come un'oscurità senza fondo anziché come avoirio insanguinato. Osservò la scena senza comprenderla per diversi secondi prima di capire infine cosa era successo. La Porta si era aperta! Lui era arrivato! Era lui Rahserat? L'uomo era raggrinzito e rattrappito. Lei lo girò She turned him over and the blood from her hands soaked immediately into his skin and disappeared. Then the snow under him did, too, and he was limned in darkness for a moment, apparently absorbing the light. He stretched and grew, withered flesh replaced with smooth skin over dense muscle. Korinna steadied herself as the hill seemed to tilt and Rahserat grew... not brighter, but everything else seemed to fade to background. But at last he become the Rahserat she dimly remembered. Then he opened his eyes. They weren't what she remembered.
TEXT.Spanish: Living yet immortal guardian of the Sleeping Emperor, and by extension all Scions of Patria. She hopes for eventual release the Sleeping Emperor. Once Risen, the Emperor will allow Korinna to act as his Regent and, always his people's Hero, go forth to destroy the Scions enemies.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Part 1: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Part 2: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE]Part 3: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Part 4: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE] In a bright land, under a bright sky, Korinna watched the mammoth herd. She wore fur and hide clothes she'd made herself, bound up with homemade leather, a stone knife at her waist. Hair streaming in the wind, she smiled at the way the huge beasts rumbled across the plain below her. It was good to see something moving, perhaps even thriving, in this frozen waste. The ash under her eyes cut the glare to something bearable, but even the glare was better than the alternating gloom and dark that marked the week-long blizzards. From the dreaming dead she knew winter. But she'd also expected to see something of the other seasons, too. No. The whole world, so far as she knew, was covered with snow and ice. She wasn't sure how much longer she could keep moving. If the food and fuel ran out... she knew she wouldn't die. Not from mere deprivation. But to be trapped here, wasted and frozen, would to be in hell. She'd throw herself off a cliff first. It had started so promisingly. A great adventure away from mother and father. She would see the living world that had born her father when he was of it, and that mother helped guard. Her mother told Korinna that while the dreams could teach her much they could never teach her everything. They were the interpreted world, not the experienced world. Other people's interpretations, never her experience. The odd hiding angel, Rahserat... she would help him enter Erebus, and then he'd be her guide there. She was to obey him. And she would, if she ever found him. Where was he? With new traveling gear lifted from the dreaming of an adventuring Queen, Korinna had taken one of her secret uncle's routes from the underworld. (Secret because he didn't know she was his niece.) Stepping into Erebus was amazing. There was air, and ground, and light in the underworld. Of course. But it wasn't the same as the air or earth or light of Erebus. She really did feel closer to the One. Or perhaps just not as oppressed by Arawn's shadow. And her journey to the Ivory Gate had been a revelation. It was also long and arduous. The snow had been the worst. She hadn't figured out how to make hide and sinew snowshoes yet. She hadn't figured out almost everything, yet. The cold was the most incredible thing. Dreamed cold was never, ever, half as painful, half as stinging, half as pervasive. Cold was not something that really existed in the dreamlands, except as a pale imitation. But she had made it to the Ivory Gate, eventually. Low on food, exhausted, she'd been looking forward to seeing Rahserat again. Both for the company and because she knew an angel's power would be of immense help in the wilderness. She'd climbed among the foothills and, guided by her mother's directions, found the Gate. She'd taken the Gate's handle in hand and pulled. If Rahserat was on the other side, it would open. But it hadn't opened. She'd arrived on the appointed day, and so she'd hauled on the gate all that day. Her hands were continually sliced by the odd barbs in the ivory, but he never came. No angel. No company. No help. That had been long ago. She watched the stars whenever visible. She kept careful records on the rock beside the gate when storms hid the stars. On the appointed day she tried the Gate every year, and every year it did not open. Korinna made a home of a deep cave a day's journey from the Gate. The great bear that had preceded her as owner furnished her with her first set of new clothes. Now she sometimes worried that she'd hunt the hills bare of large game. She recorded the courses of the stars, but she avoided recording the passage of years. She didn't want to know how long she waited. Had she been abandoned? She'd avoided men for decades. Then loneliness had set in and she'd realized they could be company, of a sort. Where before they had hunted her, having seen the smoke from her fires, she hunted them. When she found a lone hunter she'd kill him, but first give him a message to pass to her mother. The earliest ones, of course, she'd had teach her their language. Korinna couldn't trust them to carry a message unless they repeated it back it her in their own tongue. Twice she descended to the villages to seek an auger. What she was told was hopeful, but the terrified, addled woman had made no sense. There were no seasons of note in the icy wasteland, and soon her life had taken on a timeless quality. She hunted, she collected dung for fires or, occasionally, wood. But she didn't like to go far from the Gate. She composed long messages to her mother and dispatched them, along with a luckless tribesman, at intervals. When her clothes wore out she'd make new ones, or use those of a fallen tribesman. She watched the animals, sometimes hunting just to observe, not kill. And that was the scope of her days, of her life. She slept through the nights and the storms and walked under the sky only when the sun was clear and shining. In her bright land the centuries passed without mark. Until one year, on Gate day, both handles had come away in her hand. She'd hauled on them just as the sun rose and the whole elaborate cross-piece had snapped off, putting a deep cut in her right hand. She looked at the ivory in horror. The occasional day of bright sun and relative warmth had, over a great span, caused it to corrode and crumble. She'd never really known anger, or despair, until that day. She'd gone mad for a time. She'd killed every man within a day's journey, saying terrible things to her mother. She'd cursed her father, the faithless Rahserat, and the One. She'd stopped eating and nearly froze before appetite overcame her. She hadn't known it but she'd never really been hungry before, either. She almost sent herself to her mother, but to do so would be to admit defeat. Even after her black time she'd been bleak. Perhaps for years, she didn't know. But one day well after the tribes had returned, she had an idea. Maybe the first new one in centuries. She could repair the Gate. She didn't know what magic might support it, and she'd never thought about where the Gate had come from, or who'd made it. She just assumed it was something beyond time, incorruptible. But not, at least, the physical form. And that she could repair. Her hands were wise now, after mortal lifetimes of craft, and there was plenty of ivory to be had. The Gate... she could put it right. She would. And she did. With a long, stone-tipped spear and as many knives as she could easily carry, she stalked and killed a great mammoth each year. Harvesting the beast for fur, ivory, and a little leather, she'd carve and fit, taking the most time over the Gate's uncanny barbs, and shedding much blood. It became part of the annual, futile ritual that was the only punctuation to her bright, changeless days. Where was he? Rahserat had left the underworld feeling better than he had for ages. Gyra, for reasons he couldn't fathom, was a unanticipated ally. She hadn't helped him directly with his mission, true, but she still aided him in undermining Arawn, and she'd almost certainly make a better ally for his Lord than Laroth. If nothing else he could return early and report these fortuitous events to Esus. His Lord would know what to make of them. But the angel's mood had dissolved as soon as he stepped into the Hidden Queen's passageway en route for the Ivory Gate. It was not like last time. Instead it was far darker, and shot through with red lights that clung to the edge  and only the edge  of vision. Rahserat took a cautious step to the left, along the wall, and found himself instead moving somehow downwards. Another step, and the passage became even darker, and he moved further downwards. He tried to step upwards then, climb back, but the passage abruptly became pitch-black even to his vision, and the movement downward accelerated. And did not stop. Not for years. When he found himself again he was crawling across a gray stone floor toward a great stone chair. A greenish light came into the chamber through a collapsed section of wall, along with a weird and terrible smell. It was something like rot, something like the musk of a great beast, or a city. It never faded. Not over the weeks in which he crawled, or all the time in the chair itself. When he found himself seated in the chair, slowly turning to stone, the Hidden Queen finally spoke. She had been watching him crawl, he realized now. She castigated him for his betrayal, for never sending her the word she sought. Hadn't he? He thought he'd had. He'd broken his Lord's vial as soon as he'd arrived. While the Queen gloated of traps and of deities, of bait, and of snares for the One, he thought about the vial and his Lord. Had his Lord betrayed him? Had the vial done anything at all? The Hidden Queen couldn't be a comfortable ally. His Lord might have lied. That was his precept. But then, the Hidden Queen could be lying too. Or maybe his Lord had kept a secret, even if that was her precept. Perhaps he'd wanted the Queen angered at Rahserat, but not able to reach him. He, Rahserat, and broken from his Lord's thought by leaving the underworld much earlier than planned. This eldritch prison, this bizarre torture, might be the result of his own good intentions. By the time he'd thought it through, perhaps taking years, the Hidden Queen was gone. She'd said something about the end of creation. Was that where he was? The light had gone for a time, he thought, but it was back now. He could see that a stone chair across from him had eyes, and was slowly turning into a man. Not him. The shadows stirred and giggled. Their thoughts stabbed at him. His clothes had awakened from their slumber and left through the hole in the wall. He could hear them screaming as something caught and ate them. When the light turned to darkness this time he noticed that the shadows were unchanged in their dance. He realized it hadn't turned to darkness so much that the darkness had become light. Everything blurred here. His thoughts into blood, light into darkness, the living into the unliving. And the reverse, in everything. Blood to thought. Dark to light. The unliving to the living. Souls sent by the false Laroth, sent not to a location but bound instead to him, began arriving. He hid them in the stone. They began their own changes, but slowly, as slowly as he could bend time. Time was just breath, after all. As the shadows mocked him he began to understand. One thing wasn't becoming another. No, all things were one thing here. Unified. If creation was endless variety this place was the end of creation. Everything blurred together. Why the One might be here, the Rahserats couldn't say. Maybe when everything was one, they became the One? Whether that was a semantic trick or a deep truth the Queen might be able to say, but they couldn't. The shadows having been consumed, the Rahserats pulled themselves back together. He was stronger now, stronger than ever before, but stranger. He thought he might be an archangel now. He felt that powerful. But whose archangel? With the predatory shadows gone space itself grew, and grew. The chamber still had its break in the wall somewhere, but it was lost and tiny now. The immense place was full of darkness, and stone. Or things that were often darkness and stone. That was the tendency, at least for now. And now the souls were legion, but still placed in stone for relative safety. There they lost themselves in dreams far more peculiar than they'd known before. The darkness ate at Rahserat sometimes, and he writhed and ate at it. Maybe the Queen hoped the One would come to save a poor trapped angel. But he doubted it. Rahserat started skipping around in time. Perhaps rather than becoming the One, this place was the antithesis of the One. Where the One was existence, everything becoming the same as everything else was the most final sort of non-existence. If everything existed as one  or One - there could, eventually, be no change. And no new creation, for everything already existed. Maybe the One would have to come here to destroy it. Would Rahserat defend this place, this end of creation? He might. But eventually he found a time when the darkness sounded like Korinna singing. The souls in the stones actually noticed it first. The singing came not from beyond the break in the wall. He knew he could never go outside. Must not. But he didn't have to. The singing came from a point of red. He ate the red. Just the color, it was one he hadn't seen in awhile. The point remained. More points appeared, stains, and he ate the red in them too. Skipping again, he found a time when a red door stood before him. Rather than eating it, he asked his arms to push it. They did. Korinna fell away as the door broke again, and cursed. She'd thought she wouldn't have to renew the handles for three or four mammoths. A man had somehow appeared on the snow between her and the Ivory Gate, and the Gate was a bottomless darkness rather than blooded ivory. She blinked at the scene without comprehension for several moments before finally understanding. The Gate was open! He'd come! Or was this Rahserat? He was shriveled, shrunken. She turned him over and the blood from her hands soaked immediately into his skin and disappeared. Then the snow under him did, too, and he was limned in darkness for a moment, apparently absorbing the light. He stretched and grew, withered flesh replaced with smooth skin over dense muscle. Korinna steadied herself as the hill seemed to tilt and Rahserat grew... not brighter, but everything else seemed to fade to background. But at last he become the Rahserat she dimly remembered. Then he opened his eyes. They weren't what she remembered.

TEXT.English: The lord of the Scions claims to be one of Kylorin's original students, now returned from the Underworld. He says he will reclaim Erebus for the glory of Patria. The first claim is almost certainly false. As to the second, only time will tell.[PARAGRAPH:1]Other than the risen-dead few have seen the Emperor. But it is said he is surrounded by a clear, penetrating light, yet where he walks the world bends.[PARAGRAPH:1]Other leaders have learned to never insist that an envoy see the Emperor and instead prefer to deal with officers of the Apparat - An audience with the Emperor himself always leads to the acceptance of whatever terms he names. That they always seem good and fair is all the more worrying.[PARAGRAPH:1]With the Risen Emperor to watch over the Bottomless Tomb Korinna, the Tomb's immortal guardian, is free to become a Hero for the Scions. First protecting the capital, and later waging war beyond it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Part 1: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Part 2: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Part 4: In a Bright Land[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:1]In a bright land, in a white city, in a dark room a great emperor sits on a gold throne, still. Eyes of eagle-sharpness that can can look from every Mark, from the eyes of disciples, can with even greater ease look inward and long ago. To a long ago where there lay another bright land, another white city, and the throne of another great emperor. He closes his eyes, and remembers.[PARAGRAPH:1]The one who currently used the name Lareth sat up in the cart at sunrise. He was high enough in the foothills to see the plains stretch beneath him as if warmed and waked by the sun. And he was sharp sighted enough to see a herd move in the far distance. Cattle, of course. But he was sure his last mission was successful.[PARAGRAPH:1]The new wizards were uncertain of their power and more uncertain about the emperor's purposes. He could sympathize. Lareth himself wasn't entirely easy with his role. He knew he was violating the Compact's spirit even if he *arguably* abided by its rules. But his Lord assured him he wouldn't be caught, and despite everything he'd still accept his Lord's word. They had suffered the greatest possible abandonment, and his work must be done for Creation's salvation.[PARAGRAPH:1]So as Lareth he'd gone to the wizards... and merely asked questions. Could they bring greater prosperity to the plains? As a stock man (which was how he presented himself) he wanted to know if the wizards could improve his stock. Could they make the horses faster, stronger? Could they make the cattle fatter, hardier? He'd been so earnest that they'd laughed, and told him "Of course." He'd pretended anger and told them they misunderstood. He could breed faster horses, fatter cattle. All without magic. And so could the Hippus. Probably better, truth be told.[PARAGRAPH:1]What could they do that was different, with their airs and their special knowledge and their magic? Could they do better than the Horselords? Make an ox as fast as a horse? A horse as hardy as a bull... a horse that could fly? Now that would be useful. And that had caught their imaginations. Of course. It was a worthy task. It would feed more people and allow them to work harder, move faster. It would give the Patrians comfort while also making the empire stronger. One of the wizards looked disturbed, but the others were themselves comforted. They knew then that what the emperor offered was power, and it could make a better future. They knew the emperor could be trusted, for he - and they! - acted with good intentions. So there would be changling beasts on the plains... for a better future.[PARAGRAPH:1]It wasn't long before the cart stopped at a temple to Sirona. Ironic.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth hopped to the muddy road. A cold breeze ran down it, escaping the mountains, and he acted glad for his sheltering cloak. He gave the driver a few coins and hurried through the door of an inn beside the temple.[PARAGRAPH:1]The roof was low, and while ducking beams he spotted his target. She sat alone at a table against the far wall. He knew she'd been here for several days. She'd meant to leave with a south-bound caravan but had been deceived about its route. So here she'd waited for him, unknowing of their appointment. Eating well of the inn's food, he was sure, but feeding mostly on her doubts.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth skirted the near wall and took the table furthest from the bar. He didn't want to call attention to himself. Their conversation should be private and uninterrupted. How to begin it, though, was a problem. She looked skittish.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Breakfast and a drink, my lord, or just drink?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth looked up at the serving girl, and smiled. She dropped her laden tray with a tremendous clatter and every eye in the inn turned to his table. So much for obscurity. Blushing, stammering and apologizing excessively, the girl reloaded her tray. Thankfully the mugs and plates had been empty. Exerting a little influence to calm the girl, he introduced himself and ordered some soup as gently as he could. Feeling sorry for her he spread that influence over the rest of the room. Otherwise she'd be mocked. It was a little risky, but maybe it'd calm his target, too. However he decided to approach her, that'd probably help.[PARAGRAPH:1]He'd just taken his soup from the girl, who was blushing again, when a woman spoke behind him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth?"[PARAGRAPH:1]He turned. "Excuse me?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth! No..."[PARAGRAPH:1]His target. Younger than he'd thought. However much he might have calmed her earlier she was now agitated and confused.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth stood , pulling back a chair for her, and guided her into it.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hello! I'm sorry, what's wrong? Here, please sit down."[PARAGRAPH:1]She gasped a few breaths and said, "No, I'm sorry. I thought you were someone else."[PARAGRAPH:1]He sat down himself. "Well, let me make it three apologies between us: I'm sorry if I've upset you."[PARAGRAPH:1]She shook her head. "My fault. It's just that you sound like him, and what was your name...?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth, yes. It's much like his. Laroth's, I mean."[PARAGRAPH:1]"An easy mistake to make then."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You look like him too." He laughed nervously. "It's uncanny, really."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth smiled with her, to put her at ease. But he was sure she was right. His Lord had provided his name for this foray. As for his voice and appearance... He knew well that what seemed coincidence generally wasn't. Not if a god was involved. Not that you could ever be sure which god. Not anymore.[PARAGRAPH:1]Instead he said, "Please, let me make up for fate's jest. Share my table. I've been on the road for days and would appreciate conversation before I move on. My mule and I have exhausted all topics of mutual interest."[PARAGRAPH:1]She laughed delightedly at his joke, despite herself. Lareth didn't flatter himself, people always laughed his jokes. But he was glad she was at his table, his way apparently already prepared by his Lord, and that he could get this over with. He'd heard of Laroth, and what he'd heard he didn't like. While Lareth's ability to anticipate the future was nothing like his Lord's, or his Lord's peers, he could guess how his mission would shape the future for this woman.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nevertheless, he'd see it done.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Have you had breakfast yet? No?" He waved the attentive server to him. "Allow me to offer you some of this fine soup. While I wash the road's dust from my throat tell me what you're doing here."[PARAGRAPH:1]She slumped in her chair, nursing the soup, and gradually he drew her out. She must have wanted someone to talk to, it wasn't hard. Her name was Tejia, and her lover was indeed the itinerant holy man Laroth. He was starting to make a name for himself by preaching of the god Temeluchus. A being with whom Lareth was not acquainted. Tejia wouldn't denounce Laroth, but it was obvious to Lareth she knew the preacher insincere, at best.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally he volunteered some advice: "Tejia, what you both face is a crisis of faith."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes," she said. "I think I am."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm sorry, I said you both face a crisis of faith. He's clearly performing a valuable service to Patria, to the whole world, by his preaching. Yet you sense he has doubts. Strong, doubts, yes?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." She nodded uncertainly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"But you know his message is right, don't you." He made it a statement, which left her little choice.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." This time her nod was emphatic.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So you must strengthen his faith. Not everyone has equal gifts, Tejia. I'm sure you know this, but in this case I think while Laroth has a great gift for speaking, you have a greater gift for faith. Take it as a testament to his teaching that you have learned so well. But now, having learned..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia straightened in her chair and interrupted him. "Yes! My faith can strengthen his."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Very good!" Lareth looked at her encouragingly, but it was hardly needed.[PARAGRAPH:1]She smiled beatifically. "Not only was I feeling bad about doubting Laroth, but I wondered how I could contribute. Just being his... just being with him didn't seem enough. But I can serve Temeluchus, too! I can really help people see the truth."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth returned her smile. "Exactly."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thank you!" Her smile grew even brighter. "I should have seen this before." Lareth shrugged depreciatively, and she finished. "No, really. I did lack faith. But the heart will find a way if you've good intentions."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth's gaze flickered, just for an instant. He'd placed the barb and twisted this woman as his Lord wished. Probably to twist this Laroth in turn. And who knew after that? He didn't know why his Lord wanted this, but suspected the hand of the Hidden Queen. He knew she'd made certain offers to his Lord, and she'd been very active of late. But how active?[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia last remark pained him, and he wondered if someone wanted a barb in him.[PARAGRAPH:1]In a bright land in a white city, in a dark room he feels that pain anew. Such is the memory of his kind that the past may be relived as a sort of dream. This keeps both hatreds and loves, hurts and kindnesses, fresh and immune to the passage of time. Whether this makes for greater wisdom or greater folly the emperor does not know. But the dreaming is hard to resist. He believes it makes Sabathiel weak, but gives Cassiel strength. For himself he knows there's a special danger.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eyes of eagle-sharpness that can look from every Mark, from the eyes of disciples, can with even greater ease look inward and long ago. But how deeply can they see? What do they miss, and what is hidden with ill intent? He is the Angel of Good Intentions, and those he can always see, can always twist. Believing they pursue the good, men may be led very far from their chosen path. Yet to ill intentions, to deception, he's just as blind as any other being. Maybe more blind.[PARAGRAPH:1]His eyes open, he watches motes of dust play within a sunbeam now piercing the hall. It looks so real. Fully in the present again, he no longer dreams.
TEXT.French: [H1]Dans une contrée prospère[\H1][NEWLINE]Chapitre 1 : Dans une contrée prospère, l'Empereur Ressuscité[PARAGRAPH:2]Le seigneur des Scions prétend être un des élèves originels de Kylorin, aujourd'hui revenu de l'Outremonde. Il clame qu'il conquerra Erebus pour la gloire de Patria. La première assertion est certainement fausse. Pour la seconde, seul le temps nous le dira.[PARAGRAPH:1]À part les morts-vivants, peu ont vu l'Empereur. Mais on raconte qu'il est entouré d'une lumière claire et prénétrante, et pourtant, là où il marche le monde ploie.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les autres dirigeants ont appris à ne pas insister pour que leurs ambassadeurs rencontrent l'Empereur, et préfèrent faire affaire avec les officiers de l'Apparat. En effet, une audience avec l'Empereur lui-même conduit systématiquement à l'acceptation sans condition des termes émis par l'Empereur. Et qu'ils les trouvent toujours bons et justes est d'autant plus inquiétant.[PARAGRAPH:1]Comme l'Empereur Ressuscité surveille la Tombe Sans Fond de Korinna, le guardien immortel de la Tombe est libre de devenir un héros pour les Scions. D'abord en protégeant la capitale, puis en guerroyant.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dans une contrée prospère, dans une blanche ville, dans une pièce sombre un grand empereur est assis sur son trône doré, immobile. Ses yeux possèdent l'acuité de l'aigle et peuvent voir au travers de chaque Marque, des yeux de chaque disciple, et peuvent encore plus facilement scruter les esprits et le passé. Jusqu'à un passé où gisent une autre contrée prospère, une autre ville blanche, et le trône d'un autre grand empereur. Il ferme les yeux et se souvient.[PARAGRAPH:1]Celui actuellement nommé Lareth s'assit dans le chariot au lever du jour. Il était suffisamemnt haut dans les conteforts pour voir les plaines s'étirer sous lui comme si elles étaient éveillées et réchauffées par le soleil. Et il avait une assez bonne vue pour voir un troupeau se déplacer au loin. Du bétail, bien sûr. Mais il était sûr du succès de sa dernière mission.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les nouveaux magiciens étaient dubitatifs quant à leurs pouvoirs, et plus encore quant aux objectifs de l'empereur. Il pourrait sympathiser. Lareth lui-même n'était pas vraiment à l'aise avec son rôle. Il savait qu'il violait l'esprit du Pacte même s'il restait 'raisonnablement' conforme à ses règles. Mais son Seigneur lui assurait qu'il ne serait pas pris, et malgré tout il se conformerait aux instructions de son Seigneur. Ils avaient subi le pire abandon possible, et son travail devait être fait pour le salut de Création. Ainsi, sous le nom de Lareth il était parti vers les magiciens... et posa simplement des questions. Pouvaient-ils apporter la prospérité aux plaines ? En tant qu'éleveur (il s'était présenté comme tel) il voulait savoir si les magiciens pouvaient agrandir son troupeau. Pouvaient-ils rendre les chevaux plus rapides, plus forts ? Pouvaient-ils rendre le bétail plus gras, plus résistant ? Il avait été si sérieux qu'ils avaient ri, puis répondu "Bien sûr". Il simula la colère et leur dit qu'ils se trompaient. Il pouvait donner naissance à des chevaux plus rapides et du bétail plus gras. Le tout sans magie. De même que les Hippusques. Probablement meilleurs, à dire vrai.[PARAGRAPH:1]Que pouvaient-ils faire de différent, avec leurs airs, leur savoir particulier et leur magie ? Pouvaient-ils faire mieux que les Seigneurs des Chevaux ? Faire un bœuf aussi rapide qu'un cheval ? Un cheval aussi résistant qu'un taureau... un cheval capable de voler ? Aujourd'hui ça pourrait être utile. Et ça a stimulé leur imagination. Évidemment. C'était une tâche louable. Ça nourrirrait plus de gens, et leur permettrait de travailler plus dur, de se déplacer plus vite. Ça procurerait aux Patriens plus de confort tout en renforçant l'empire. Un des magiciens sembla troublé, mais les autres achevèrent de se convaincre. Ils savaient alors que ce que l'empereur leur offrait était le pouvoir et qu'il pouvait créer un futur meilleur. Ils savaient qu'ils pouvaient faire confiance à l'empereur, car il (et eux aussi !) agissaient avec de nobles intentions. Il y aurait donc des bêtes mutantes dans les plaines... pour un futur meilleur.[PARAGRAPH:1]Peu après le chariot s'arrêta à un temple de Sirona. Ironique.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth sauta sur la route boueuse. Un vent froid descendait le long de la route, s'échappant des montagnes, et il fut heureux de porter sont manteau protecteur. Il donna au conducteur quelques pièces et se pressa vers la porte d'une auberge située à côté du temple.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le plafond était bas, et il repéra sa cible au milieu de la foule. Elle était assise seule à une table collée au mur du fond. Il savait qu'elle était là depuis plusieurs jours. Elle était censée partir avec une caravane du sud, mais s'était méprise sur sa route. Ainsi elle l'attendait là, inconsciente de leur rendez-vous. Mangeant convenablement à l'auberge, il en était sûr, mais se nourissant principalement de ses doutes.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth longea le mur proche et s'attabla le plus loin possible du bar. Il ne souhaitait pas attirer l'attention. Leur conversation devait être privée et ininterrompue. Comment la démarrer était cependant un problème. Elle semblait nerveuse.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Petit-déjeuner et boisson, mon seigneur, ou juste une boisson ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth leva les yeux vers la serveuse et sourit. Elle lâcha son plateau dans un fracas assourdissant et tous les yeux se tournèrent vers sa table. Autant pour la discrétion. Rougissante, bégayant et s'excusant à outrance, la fille récupéra son plateau. Heureusement les choppes et les assiettes étaient vides. Faisant en sorte de calmer la fille, il se présenta et commanda de la soupe aussi gentiment qu'il le pût. Se senant désolé pour elle il étendit son influence au reste de la pièce. Elle aurait sinon été raillée. C'était un peu risqué, mais peut-être que ça calmerait également sa cible. Totuefois il décida de s'approcher d'elle, et ceci l'aiderait probablement.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il venait de se faire servir sa soupe par la fille qui rougissait à nouveau quand une femme parla derrière lui.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Il se retourna. "Excusez-moi ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth ! Non..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Sa cible, plus jeune qu'il ne le pensait. Quel que soit le calme qu'il lui avait imposée elle était maintenant nerveuse et confuse. Lareth se leva, recula une chaise à son attention et la guida pour s'asseoir.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bonjour ! Je suis désolé, quelque chose ne va pas ? Venez, asseyez-vous s'il vous plait."[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle haleta un peu et répondit, "Non, je suis désolée. Je vous ai pris pour un autre."[PARAGRAPH:1]Il s'assit. "Et bien, laissez moi en faire une triple excuse : je suis désolé si je vous ai fâchée."[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle secoua la tête. "C'est ma faute. C'est jsute que vous avez la même voix que lui, et quel était votre nom... ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth, oui. Ça y ressemble beaucoup. Laroth, je veux dire."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Une confusion facile, donc."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Vous lui ressemblez également." Elle rit nerveusement. "C'est vraiment troublant."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth lui sourit, pour la mettre à l'aise. Mais il était sûr qu'elle avait raison. son Seigneur lui avait donné ce nom pour cette incursion. De même que cette voix et cette apparence... Il savait pertinemment que ce qui pouvait sembler être une coïncidence ne l'était généralement pas. Pas si un dieu était impliqué. Encore que vous ne pouvez jamais en être sûr de quel dieu. Plus maintenant.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il répondit plutôt, "S'il vous plait, laissez-moi m'excuser pour ce coup du destin. Asseyez-vous à ma table. Je suis sur la route depuis des jours, et j'apprécierais un peu de conversation avant de repartir. Ma mule et moi avons épuisé tous nous sujets d'intérêt commun."[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle rit de bon cœur à sa blague, malgré elle. Lareth ne s'en flatta pas, les gens riaient toujours à ses blagues. Mais il était heureux de la voir à sa table, son chemin apparemment déjà tracé par son Seigneur afin qu'il s'en sorte. Il avait entendu aprler de Laroth et ce qu'il avait entendu ne lui avait pas plu. Bien que la capacité de Lareth à prévoir le futur n'était rien comparée à celle de son Seigneur ou de Ses égaux, il pouvait deviner comment sa mission modifierait le futur de cette femme.Toutefois ce devait être fait.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Avez-vous déjà pris votre petit-déjeuner ? Non ?" Il attira la serveuse attentive à lui. "Permettez moi de vous offrir un peu de cette bonne soupe. Tandis que je décrasse mon gosier de la poussière de la route, dites moi ce que vous venez faire ici."[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle s'affaissa sur sa chaise, penchée sur sa soupe, et il l'en sortit progressivement. Elle devait avoir voulu quelqu'un pour se confier, ce fut donc facile. Son nom était Tejia, et son amant était effectivement le saint homme itinérant Laroth. Il commençait à se faire un nom en prêchant au nom du dieu Temeluchus. Un être inconnu de Lareth. Tejia ne trahirait jamais Laroth, mais il était clair pour Lareth qu'elle savait le prêcheur non sincère au mieux.[PARAGRAPH:1] Il donna finalement un conseil : "Tejia, ce que vous traversez tous les deux est une crise de foi."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui," répondit-elle, "je crois aussi que c'est ce qu'il m'arrive."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Excusez-moi, je disais que vous traversiez tous les deux une crise de foi. Il rend clairement un grand service à Patria, au monde entier, en prêchant. Et pourtant vous sentez qu'il a des doutes. De gros doutes, n'est-ce pas ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui." Elle acquiesca timidement.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mais vous savez que son message est vrai, hein." Il l'avait affirmé, lui laissant peu de choix.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui." Cette fois son signe de tête était empathique.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Vous devez donc renforcer sa foi. Tout le monde ne dispose pas des mêmes dons, Tejia. Je suis sûr que vous les savez, mais dans votre cas, je pense que Laroth a un vrai don d'éloquence, tandis que votre don réside dans votre foi. Prenez-le comme un testament de ses enseignements que vousa vez si bien appris. Mais maintenant, l'avoir appris..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia se redresa sur sa haise et l'interrompit. "Oui ! Ma foi peut renforcer la sienne."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Bien !" Lareth la regarda en l'encourageant, mais ce n'était pas vraiment nécesaire.[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle sourit béatement. "Non seulement je me sentais mal de douter de Laroth, mais en plus je me demandais comment l'aider. N'être que son... n'être qu'avec lui ne semblait pas assez. Mais je peux servir Temeluchus aussi ! Je peux vraiment aider les gens à ouvrir les yeux."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth lui rendit son sourire. "Exactement."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Merci !" Son sourire devient encore plus éclatant. "J'aurais dû le voir plus tôt." Lareth haussa modestement les épaules, et elle poursuivit. "non, vraiment. J'ai manqué de foi. Mais votre cœur trouvera un moyen si vous avez de bonnes intentions."[PARAGRAPH:1]Le regard de Lareth vacilla un instant. Il avait tendu son piège et y avait pris cete femme comme le souhaitait son Seigneur. Proabalement pour pièger ce Laroth en retour. Et après qui sait ? Il ne savait pas pourquoi son Seigneur le souhaitait, mais il y suspectait la main de la Reine Cachée. Il savait qu'elle avait fait des offres à son Seigneur, et elle avait été très active dernièrement. Mais active dans quel sens ?[PARAGRAPH:1]La dernière remarque de Tejia lui fit de la peine, et se demanda si quelqu'un cherchait à lui nuire.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dans une contrée prospère, dans une ville blanche, dans une pièce sombre, il ressentit à nouveau cette peine. Les souvenirs de ses pairs sont ainsi faits que le passé peut être revécu comme une sorte de rêve. Ça préserve les haines et les amours, les blessures et les gentillesses comme au premier jour. Que cela mène à une sagesse plus profonde ou à une folie plus intense, l'empereur l'ignorait. Mais il est difficile de résister au rêve. Il crois qu'il affaiblit Sabathiel, mais renforce Cassiel. Pour lui-même il est conscient d'un danger particulier.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ses yeux possèdent l'acuité de l'aigle et peuvent voir au travers de chaque Marque, des yeux de chaque disciple, et peuvent encore plus facilement scruter les esprits et le passé. Mais jusqu'où peuvent-ils voir ? Qu'est-ce qui leur échappe, et qu'est-ce qui est caché avec de mauvaises intentions ? Il est l'Ange des Bonnes Intentions, et ceux qu'il peut toujours voir, peuvent toujours se corrompre. En croyant suivre la voie du bien, les hommes peuvent être menés bien loin de leur chemin choisi. Et pourtant, vis à vis des mauvaises intentions, des trahisons, il est tout aussi aveugle que n'importe qui. Peut-être même plus.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ses yeux ouverts, il observe des grains de poussière jouant dans le rayon de soleil qui perce l'entrée. Ça semble si réel. Complètement revenu dans le présent, il ne rêve plus.[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Chapitre 2 : Dans une contrée prospère, l'Éveillé[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Chapitre 3 : Dans une contrée prospère, Korinna[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Chapitre 4 : Dans une contrée prospère, la Cathédrale de la Renaissance[\LINK]
TEXT.German: The lord of the Scions claims to be one of Kylorin's original students, now returned from the Underworld. He says he will reclaim Erebus for the glory of Patria. The first claim is almost certainly false. As to the second, only time will tell.[PARAGRAPH:1]Other than the risen-dead few have seen the Emperor. But it is said he is surrounded by a clear, penetrating light, yet where he walks the world bends.[PARAGRAPH:1]Other leaders have learned to never insist that an envoy see the Emperor and instead prefer to deal with officers of the Apparat - An audience with the Emperor himself always leads to the acceptance of whatever terms he names. That they always seem good and fair is all the more worrying.[PARAGRAPH:1]With the Risen Emperor to watch over the Bottomless Tomb Korinna, the Tomb's immortal guardian, is free to become a Hero for the Scions. First protecting the capital, and later waging war beyond it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Part 1: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Part 2: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Part 4: In a Bright Land[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:1]In a bright land, in a white city, in a dark room a great emperor sits on a gold throne, still. Eyes of eagle-sharpness that can can look from every Mark, from the eyes of disciples, can with even greater ease look inward and long ago. To a long ago where there lay another bright land, another white city, and the throne of another great emperor. He closes his eyes, and remembers.[PARAGRAPH:1]The one who currently used the name Lareth sat up in the cart at sunrise. He was high enough in the foothills to see the plains stretch beneath him as if warmed and waked by the sun. And he was sharp sighted enough to see a herd move in the far distance. Cattle, of course. But he was sure his last mission was successful.[PARAGRAPH:1]The new wizards were uncertain of their power and more uncertain about the emperor's purposes. He could sympathize. Lareth himself wasn't entirely easy with his role. He knew he was violating the Compact's spirit even if he *arguably* abided by its rules. But his Lord assured him he wouldn't be caught, and despite everything he'd still accept his Lord's word. They had suffered the greatest possible abandonment, and his work must be done for Creation's salvation.[PARAGRAPH:1]So as Lareth he'd gone to the wizards... and merely asked questions. Could they bring greater prosperity to the plains? As a stock man (which was how he presented himself) he wanted to know if the wizards could improve his stock. Could they make the horses faster, stronger? Could they make the cattle fatter, hardier? He'd been so earnest that they'd laughed, and told him "Of course." He'd pretended anger and told them they misunderstood. He could breed faster horses, fatter cattle. All without magic. And so could the Hippus. Probably better, truth be told.[PARAGRAPH:1]What could they do that was different, with their airs and their special knowledge and their magic? Could they do better than the Horselords? Make an ox as fast as a horse? A horse as hardy as a bull... a horse that could fly? Now that would be useful. And that had caught their imaginations. Of course. It was a worthy task. It would feed more people and allow them to work harder, move faster. It would give the Patrians comfort while also making the empire stronger. One of the wizards looked disturbed, but the others were themselves comforted. They knew then that what the emperor offered was power, and it could make a better future. They knew the emperor could be trusted, for he - and they! - acted with good intentions. So there would be changling beasts on the plains... for a better future.[PARAGRAPH:1]It wasn't long before the cart stopped at a temple to Sirona. Ironic.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth hopped to the muddy road. A cold breeze ran down it, escaping the mountains, and he acted glad for his sheltering cloak. He gave the driver a few coins and hurried through the door of an inn beside the temple.[PARAGRAPH:1]The roof was low, and while ducking beams he spotted his target. She sat alone at a table against the far wall. He knew she'd been here for several days. She'd meant to leave with a south-bound caravan but had been deceived about its route. So here she'd waited for him, unknowing of their appointment. Eating well of the inn's food, he was sure, but feeding mostly on her doubts.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth skirted the near wall and took the table furthest from the bar. He didn't want to call attention to himself. Their conversation should be private and uninterrupted. How to begin it, though, was a problem. She looked skittish.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Breakfast and a drink, my lord, or just drink?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth looked up at the serving girl, and smiled. She dropped her laden tray with a tremendous clatter and every eye in the inn turned to his table. So much for obscurity. Blushing, stammering and apologizing excessively, the girl reloaded her tray. Thankfully the mugs and plates had been empty. Exerting a little influence to calm the girl, he introduced himself and ordered some soup as gently as he could. Feeling sorry for her he spread that influence over the rest of the room. Otherwise she'd be mocked. It was a little risky, but maybe it'd calm his target, too. However he decided to approach her, that'd probably help.[PARAGRAPH:1]He'd just taken his soup from the girl, who was blushing again, when a woman spoke behind him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth?"[PARAGRAPH:1]He turned. "Excuse me?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth! No..."[PARAGRAPH:1]His target. Younger than he'd thought. However much he might have calmed her earlier she was now agitated and confused.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth stood , pulling back a chair for her, and guided her into it.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hello! I'm sorry, what's wrong? Here, please sit down."[PARAGRAPH:1]She gasped a few breaths and said, "No, I'm sorry. I thought you were someone else."[PARAGRAPH:1]He sat down himself. "Well, let me make it three apologies between us: I'm sorry if I've upset you."[PARAGRAPH:1]She shook her head. "My fault. It's just that you sound like him, and what was your name...?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth, yes. It's much like his. Laroth's, I mean."[PARAGRAPH:1]"An easy mistake to make then."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You look like him too." He laughed nervously. "It's uncanny, really."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth smiled with her, to put her at ease. But he was sure she was right. His Lord had provided his name for this foray. As for his voice and appearance... He knew well that what seemed coincidence generally wasn't. Not if a god was involved. Not that you could ever be sure which god. Not anymore.[PARAGRAPH:1]Instead he said, "Please, let me make up for fate's jest. Share my table. I've been on the road for days and would appreciate conversation before I move on. My mule and I have exhausted all topics of mutual interest."[PARAGRAPH:1]She laughed delightedly at his joke, despite herself. Lareth didn't flatter himself, people always laughed his jokes. But he was glad she was at his table, his way apparently already prepared by his Lord, and that he could get this over with. He'd heard of Laroth, and what he'd heard he didn't like. While Lareth's ability to anticipate the future was nothing like his Lord's, or his Lord's peers, he could guess how his mission would shape the future for this woman.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nevertheless, he'd see it done.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Have you had breakfast yet? No?" He waved the attentive server to him. "Allow me to offer you some of this fine soup. While I wash the road's dust from my throat tell me what you're doing here."[PARAGRAPH:1]She slumped in her chair, nursing the soup, and gradually he drew her out. She must have wanted someone to talk to, it wasn't hard. Her name was Tejia, and her lover was indeed the itinerant holy man Laroth. He was starting to make a name for himself by preaching of the god Temeluchus. A being with whom Lareth was not acquainted. Tejia wouldn't denounce Laroth, but it was obvious to Lareth she knew the preacher insincere, at best.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally he volunteered some advice: "Tejia, what you both face is a crisis of faith."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes," she said. "I think I am."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm sorry, I said you both face a crisis of faith. He's clearly performing a valuable service to Patria, to the whole world, by his preaching. Yet you sense he has doubts. Strong, doubts, yes?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." She nodded uncertainly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"But you know his message is right, don't you." He made it a statement, which left her little choice.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." This time her nod was emphatic.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So you must strengthen his faith. Not everyone has equal gifts, Tejia. I'm sure you know this, but in this case I think while Laroth has a great gift for speaking, you have a greater gift for faith. Take it as a testament to his teaching that you have learned so well. But now, having learned..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia straightened in her chair and interrupted him. "Yes! My faith can strengthen his."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Very good!" Lareth looked at her encouragingly, but it was hardly needed.[PARAGRAPH:1]She smiled beatifically. "Not only was I feeling bad about doubting Laroth, but I wondered how I could contribute. Just being his... just being with him didn't seem enough. But I can serve Temeluchus, too! I can really help people see the truth."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth returned her smile. "Exactly."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thank you!" Her smile grew even brighter. "I should have seen this before." Lareth shrugged depreciatively, and she finished. "No, really. I did lack faith. But the heart will find a way if you've good intentions."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth's gaze flickered, just for an instant. He'd placed the barb and twisted this woman as his Lord wished. Probably to twist this Laroth in turn. And who knew after that? He didn't know why his Lord wanted this, but suspected the hand of the Hidden Queen. He knew she'd made certain offers to his Lord, and she'd been very active of late. But how active?[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia last remark pained him, and he wondered if someone wanted a barb in him.[PARAGRAPH:1]In a bright land in a white city, in a dark room he feels that pain anew. Such is the memory of his kind that the past may be relived as a sort of dream. This keeps both hatreds and loves, hurts and kindnesses, fresh and immune to the passage of time. Whether this makes for greater wisdom or greater folly the emperor does not know. But the dreaming is hard to resist. He believes it makes Sabathiel weak, but gives Cassiel strength. For himself he knows there's a special danger.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eyes of eagle-sharpness that can look from every Mark, from the eyes of disciples, can with even greater ease look inward and long ago. But how deeply can they see? What do they miss, and what is hidden with ill intent? He is the Angel of Good Intentions, and those he can always see, can always twist. Believing they pursue the good, men may be led very far from their chosen path. Yet to ill intentions, to deception, he's just as blind as any other being. Maybe more blind.[PARAGRAPH:1]His eyes open, he watches motes of dust play within a sunbeam now piercing the hall. It looks so real. Fully in the present again, he no longer dreams.

However he decided to approach her, that'd probably help.[PARAGRAPH:1]He'd just taken his soup from the girl, who was blushing again, when a woman spoke behind him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth?"[PARAGRAPH:1]He turned. "Excuse me?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Laroth! No..."[PARAGRAPH:1]His target. Younger than he'd thought. However much he might have calmed her earlier she was now agitated and confused.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth stood , pulling back a chair for her, and guided her into it.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hello! I'm sorry, what's wrong? Here, please sit down."[PARAGRAPH:1]She gasped a few breaths and said, "No, I'm sorry. I thought you were someone else."[PARAGRAPH:1]He sat down himself. "Well, let me make it three apologies between us: I'm sorry if I've upset you."[PARAGRAPH:1]She shook her head. "My fault. It's just that you sound like him, and what was your name...?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Lareth, yes. It's much like his. Laroth's, I mean."[PARAGRAPH:1]"An easy mistake to make then."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You look like him too." He laughed nervously. "It's uncanny, really."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth smiled with her, to put her at ease. But he was sure she was right. His Lord had provided his name for this foray. As for his voice and appearance... He knew well that what seemed coincidence generally wasn't. Not if a god was involved. Not that you could ever be sure which god. Not anymore.[PARAGRAPH:1]Instead he said, "Please, let me make up for fate's jest. Share my table. I've been on the road for days and would appreciate conversation before I move on. My mule and I have exhausted all topics of mutual interest."[PARAGRAPH:1]She laughed delightedly at his joke, despite herself. Lareth didn't flatter himself, people always laughed his jokes. But he was glad she was at his table, his way apparently already prepared by his Lord, and that he could get this over with. He'd heard of Laroth, and what he'd heard he didn't like. While Lareth's ability to anticipate the future was nothing like his Lord's, or his Lord's peers, he could guess how his mission would shape the future for this woman.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nevertheless, he'd see it done.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Have you had breakfast yet? No?" He waved the attentive server to him. "Allow me to offer you some of this fine soup. While I wash the road's dust from my throat tell me what you're doing here."[PARAGRAPH:1]She slumped in her chair, nursing the soup, and gradually he drew her out. She must have wanted someone to talk to, it wasn't hard. Her name was Tejia, and her lover was indeed the itinerant holy man Laroth. He was starting to make a name for himself by preaching of the god Temeluchus. A being with whom Lareth was not acquainted. Tejia wouldn't denounce Laroth, but it was obvious to Lareth she knew the preacher insincere, at best.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally he volunteered some advice: "Tejia, what you both face is a crisis of faith."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes," she said. "I think I am."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm sorry, I said you both face a crisis of faith. He's clearly performing a valuable service to Patria, to the whole world, by his preaching. Yet you sense he has doubts. Strong, doubts, yes?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." She nodded uncertainly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"But you know his message is right, don't you." He made it a statement, which left her little choice.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes." This time her nod was emphatic.[PARAGRAPH:1]"So you must strengthen his faith. Not everyone has equal gifts, Tejia. I'm sure you know this, but in this case I think while Laroth has a great gift for speaking, you have a greater gift for faith. Take it as a testament to his teaching that you have learned so well. But now, having learned..."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia straightened in her chair and interrupted him. "Yes! My faith can strengthen his."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Very good!" Lareth looked at her encouragingly, but it was hardly needed.[PARAGRAPH:1]She smiled beatifically. "Not only was I feeling bad about doubting Laroth, but I wondered how I could contribute. Just being his... just being with him didn't seem enough. But I can serve Temeluchus, too! I can really help people see the truth."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth returned her smile. "Exactly."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thank you!" Her smile grew even brighter. "I should have seen this before." Lareth shrugged depreciatively, and she finished. "No, really. I did lack faith. But the heart will find a way if you've good intentions."[PARAGRAPH:1]Lareth's gaze flickered, just for an instant. He'd placed the barb and twisted this woman as his Lord wished. Probably to twist this Laroth in turn. And who knew after that? He didn't know why his Lord wanted this, but suspected the hand of the Hidden Queen. He knew she'd made certain offers to his Lord, and she'd been very active of late. But how active?[PARAGRAPH:1]Tejia last remark pained him, and he wondered if someone wanted a barb in him.[PARAGRAPH:1]In a bright land in a white city, in a dark room he feels that pain anew. Such is the memory of his kind that the past may be relived as a sort of dream. This keeps both hatreds and loves, hurts and kindnesses, fresh and immune to the passage of time. Whether this makes for greater wisdom or greater folly the emperor does not know. But the dreaming is hard to resist. He believes it makes Sabathiel weak, but gives Cassiel strength. For himself he knows there's a special danger.[PARAGRAPH:1]Eyes of eagle-sharpness that can look from every Mark, from the eyes of disciples, can with even greater ease look inward and long ago. But how deeply can they see? What do they miss, and what is hidden with ill intent? He is the Angel of Good Intentions, and those he can always see, can always twist. Believing they pursue the good, men may be led very far from their chosen path. Yet to ill intentions, to deception, he's just as blind as any other being. Maybe more blind.[PARAGRAPH:1]His eyes open, he watches motes of dust play within a sunbeam now piercing the hall. It looks so real. Fully in the present again, he no longer dreams.

TEXT.English: The Opening of the Way: A passage from the End of Creation, through the Underworld, and to Erebus is temporarily opened. Many Scions, including the False Laroth, enter Erebus at a random location. Triggered by Themoch, and requireing 'Sorcery'. The more advanced the Scions are technologically the more units may be brought through. Arcane techs tend to grant Arcane units, Economic techs supplies, Military techs military units and Religious techs Awakened. The Help pop up will give a unit total by type. The wind rushes up the hillside without noise, swallowed whole by a hungry sky. The lone rider's gently flapping, twisting mantle is the only sign of its passage. The rider too is silent. The hooves of his horse strike the ground without sound or sign. The beast itself never whinnies or nickers, or vocalizes in any way. The rider, Themoch, sometimes seems to. His lips move in a silent curse as he reigns his horse on the barren hilltop and dismounts to the bloody ground. Another silent man and horse are here, though entirely without motion. Neither will move again. The horse looks to have died from multiple arrow wounds, but the man was hacked apart. Themoch reads no malice into the act. Being an imperial soldier that's exactly what was needed. He checks the man's torso. No message pouch, and no message. Probably destroyed or, worse, taken. But Themoch extends his search and finally locates the messenger's right arm. Looking, he finds grit under the nails. It isn't long before he finds the shallow hiding hole, and the pouch. In the pouch is a single terse message: "Let the Breach open. Tell him." Themoch checks the seals. The note is from the Emperor's own hand. An enemy finding this wouldn't have know the import of this short message, but Themoch does. Even so, he doesn't hesitate. He rises from his crouch and again moves his lips as if speaking. Still without sound. No ears on that hill, no matter how sensitive, would hear a word. Only a lip reader could have made out any meaning. And yet... in another place entirely a man without eyes hears Themoch, as he always hears Themoch. His crowned head lifts at the sound of his name, and he hears Themoch's own short message. [ITALICS]"Come and see!"[\ITALICS]

TEXT.English: Honor to the Archon! The Doomgiver takes the title "Archon" and governorship over a city and surrounding countryside. The lines of destiny twist with his will, at his whim. With Chance the priesthood's mistress efficiency increases, the city sparkles, and dissenters tend to meet unfortunate accidents. The benefits of accepting Patria Reborn become very clear, the penalties for rejecting her very imminent.
TEXT.French: Gloire à l'Archon ! L'Exécuteur prend le titre d'"Archon" et le rôle de gouverneur d'une ville et de ses environs. Les fils du destin se mouvent selon sa volonté, selon ses caprices. Grâce à la Chance, l'efficacité de la grande prêtresse augmente, la ville prospère, et les fauteurs de troubles ont tendance à être victimes de malheureux accidents. Les avantages à accepter Patria Ressuscitée deviennent très clairs, et les risques à la rejeter très concrets.
