TEXT.English: [LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Part 1: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Part 2: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE]Part 4: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE] In a bright land, in a bright city, on a bright throne the Emperor remembers. He remembers taking Korinna's stone knives and driving them through the Ivory Gate. They sank into the softer stone behind the open door, pinning it open. He remembers the first expeditions beyond the Gate, into what was now called the Bottomless Tomb. In his absence the dead got on with their weird, slow dreaming, and had to be enticed out with offerings and pleadings. The Emperor, Rahserat, wondered just how much of their living existence they spent dreaming. If they never really stopped and only met each other only where their dreams intersected. Whether they ever really lived in the deciphered world. They never dreamed in the vaults of Agares and his allies. Maybe thats what hell was, to have imposed on you the dreams of others. But for an angel the dreaming-that-is-memory must eventually give way to action. To decision. Now he wanted a messenger, and one of his guards left to summon one. Another brought pen, ink, and vellum. When the agent stood before him Rahserat had a scroll ready. There would be a new campaign, and it was time for the opening of the way. From the end of creation, through the underworld, and into Erebus. The Breach. He'd soon see that long separated reflection of himself, the false Laroth. What had it grown into, he wondered. Gyra would know of the Breach immediately. Would she see this as a fulfillment of her plans, or a betrayal? [ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS] Enough of memory, now he had another decision to make. The army from beyond the Breach was necessary whether he attacked or consolidated his empire. But should he attack, or just hold? This was a critical time, a pivot, and whether or not the Scions declared now for the forces of rising Armageddon or waited, hoping for greater effect later, could decide the fate of the world. To wait might be to wait too long. What would his Lord have him do? The world must be saved. He wanted only the best... [ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS] A ringing and clattering shattered the quiet of the throne room as a hundred guardswomen all fell as one. The Emperor went still and cold. Finally, he understood what she meant. Everything: Nemed's trials, Mammon speaking before the assembled ranks, the War, the Compact, flashed through his mind. Iaegus' pointed cruelties. Esus' plots and plans. The God of Deception. And Trust. Rahserat had acted only as he thought was best for the world. He had gone against the revealed will of the One, yes, but he had acted only with the best of intentions. It was a minor precept, but he'd never abandoned it! Never corrupted it. He had been deceived, or at least led astray, but he had never abandoned his precept. He had never fallen. In a bright land, on a bright throne, in a room where a hundred identical women lie unconscious, with the guards outside hammering on the door, desperate to know if their Emperor is safe, their Emperor doubts his safety. He had never fallen. But now he could. He had been persuaded, before. He had been mistaken. Even an angel, obeying his purpose, can be twisted around that purpose. Yet from the moment he'd realized that no fall was behind him, a gulf opened before him. He could stay consistent with all his past actions over these many millennia. He could stay true to his Lord and creator. He really could be part of saving the world. Or... Before he had been thoughtless or deceived, now he could choose. He could stay the Angel of Good Intentions, or become the Angel of Regret. Which was he? Rahserat went cold a second time, and the hammering at the doors abruptly stopped. There was a further danger. He knew his Lord as well as any could. Rahserat had survived the betrayal of the Hidden Queen. Perhaps only, he now wondered, because at the time he was unfallen. Maybe the One really had helped him. He had also escaped the god of Death. He had been taken in by an archangel, and even given charge of her daughter. He ruled a vast empire on Erebus, leading armies for the greater glory of... something. Or did he? He had been very, very fortunate. But his Lord trusted no one, and in his vault casually played games with time and perception. Esus toyed with dreams, and always twisted them. The Risen Emperor might be emperor of only one of Esus' dreams. And he'd never know, never know for sure, until he'd acted in any way that revealed himself. Regret or Good Intentions. He could put it off, but there was no such thing as a non-decision. Delay was something he could only... regret. Rahserat knew he had to choose.

He knew his Lord as well as any could. Rahserat had survived the betrayal of the Hidden Queen. Perhaps only, he now wondered, because at the time he was unfallen. Maybe the One really had helped him. He had also escaped the god of Death. He had been taken in by an archangel, and even given charge of her daughter. He ruled a vast empire on Erebus, leading armies for the greater glory of... something. Or did he? He had been very, very fortunate. But his Lord trusted no one, and in his vault casually played games with time and perception. Esus toyed with dreams, and always twisted them. The Risen Emperor might be emperor of only one of Esus' dreams. And he'd never know, never know for sure, until he'd acted in any way that revealed himself. Regret or Good Intentions. He could put it off, but there was no such thing as a non-decision. Delay was something he could only... regret. Rahserat knew he had to choose.
TEXT.German: [LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Part 1: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_2]Part 2: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE]Part 4: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE] In a bright land, in a bright city, on a bright throne the Emperor remembers. He remembers taking Korinna's stone knives and driving them through the Ivory Gate. They sank into the softer stone behind the open door, pinning it open. He remembers the first expeditions beyond the Gate, into what was now called the Bottomless Tomb. In his absence the dead got on with their weird, slow dreaming, and had to be enticed out with offerings and pleadings. The Emperor, Rahserat, wondered just how much of their living existence they spent dreaming. If they never really stopped and only met each other only where their dreams intersected. Whether they ever really lived in the deciphered world. They never dreamed in the vaults of Agares and his allies. Maybe thats what hell was, to have imposed on you the dreams of others. But for an angel the dreaming-that-is-memory must eventually give way to action. To decision. Now he wanted a messenger, and one of his guards left to summon one. Another brought pen, ink, and vellum. When the agent stood before him Rahserat had a scroll ready. There would be a new campaign, and it was time for the opening of the way. From the end of creation, through the underworld, and into Erebus. The Breach. He'd soon see that long separated reflection of himself, the false Laroth. What had it grown into, he wondered. Gyra would know of the Breach immediately. Would she see this as a fulfillment of her plans, or a betrayal? [ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS] Enough of memory, now he had another decision to make. The army from beyond the Breach was necessary whether he attacked or consolidated his empire. But should he attack, or just hold? This was a critical time, a pivot, and whether or not the Scions declared now for the forces of rising Armageddon or waited, hoping for greater effect later, could decide the fate of the world. To wait might be to wait too long. What would his Lord have him do? The world must be saved. He wanted only the best... [ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS] A ringing and clattering shattered the quiet of the throne room as a hundred guardswomen all fell as one. The Emperor went still and cold. Finally, he understood what she meant. Everything: Nemed's trials, Mammon speaking before the assembled ranks, the War, the Compact, flashed through his mind. Iaegus' pointed cruelties. Esus' plots and plans. The God of Deception. And Trust. Rahserat had acted only as he thought was best for the world. He had gone against the revealed will of the One, yes, but he had acted only with the best of intentions. It was a minor precept, but he'd never abandoned it! Never corrupted it. He had been deceived, or at least led astray, but he had never abandoned his precept. He had never fallen. In a bright land, on a bright throne, in a room where a hundred identical women lie unconscious, with the guards outside hammering on the door, desperate to know if their Emperor is safe, their Emperor doubts his safety. He had never fallen. But now he could. He had been persuaded, before. He had been mistaken. Even an angel, obeying his purpose, can be twisted around that purpose. Yet from the moment he'd realized that no fall was behind him, a gulf opened before him. He could stay consistent with all his past actions over these many millennia. He could stay true to his Lord and creator. He really could be part of saving the world. Or... Before he had been thoughtless or deceived, now he could choose. He could put it off, but there was no such thing as a non-decision. Delay was something he could only... regret. Rahserat knew he had to choose.

TEXT.English: The Cathedral of Rebirth celebrates the glory of both the Emperor and the people. The Cathedrals tie the empire together with self-veneration. It is in the Cathedrals that the chosen of the new age's people are ceremoniously made into true Scions of Patria. Eventually the Bottomless Tomb becomes too difficult to reach, and Cathedrals of Rebirth become the main peaceful source of new population.

TEXT.English: Body mana can't be used by the Gifted in the ordinary manner... but rather, in an extraordinary manner. At the capital's Flesh Studio adepts mold flesh like clay, or work it like metal, or weave it like silk.[PARAGRAPH:1]Most citizens apply to the Studio to improve their appearance, but it also allows soldiers to quickly and easily become terrifying.[PARAGRAPH:1]Vanity and health combine to make the Flesh Studio a powerful lure of those Awakened still lingering in the Tomb. The more Body mana available, the more powerful the lure.

TEXT.English: Various entertainments celebrating the Emperor and the Gift, including plays, are performed here. Where a Temple of the Gift is often the main link to the capital, a Hall of the Covenant is often the center of a city's secular life.[PARAGRAPH:1]Awakened are part of the Covenant. A Hall increases the likelihood that an Awakened will emerge from the Bottomless Tomb.

TEXT.English: A center for the worship of Kylorin as the supreme Archmage and savior of humankind. Frowned on by the Emperor's Cult because it shifts veneration away from the Risen Emperor. Frowned on by the Church of the Gift for undermining the Doomsayer's authority. Frowned on by the local authorities because mage-wannabees tend toward spontaneously bursting into unquenchable flame.

TEXT.English: All citizens of Patria Reborn possess the Gift of Life-in-Death, but each city has populations of living people as well. These immigrants labor for the good of the Scions. The most worthy never truly die, but will instead receive the flesh imperishable. [PARAGRAPH:1] With Sorcery the Scions have regained sufficient knowledge to give the Gift to others. And not just a chosen few, but on a massive scale. All long-term citizens will now gradually join the ranks of the undead. Whether they want to or not. Energy from all living things in the region is funneled into the city's Mages Guilds or workshops and put to good use.

TEXT.English: The Gift is the gift of unlife Scions receive from their Emperor. The Scions do not worship death. Rather the Temples host a fiercely nationalistic faith worshiping the Emperor and the proud history of Patria. The Legates tell and re-tell the story of their history: Glory, then betrayal by the gods and their thuggish angels. The long cold, the long fitful sleep... and now the Gift and rebirth.[PARAGRAPH:1]A Temple of the Gift increases the likelihood that an Awakened will leave the Bottomless Tomb.

TEXT.English: The story goes that Alcinus would have been one of Kylorin's students, but was rejected for two reasons. First, Alcinus is of such great potential that even the great Kylorin was forced to know envy. Second, Alcinus is completely, irretrievably, and violently mad.[PARAGRAPH:1]When enraged he may become so furious he completely loses control. If Alcinus turns on the Emperor or his Regent the only course is hunting him down and destroying him. The rest will calm him, wiping his mind of the delusions and fears that led to his last break. But after a short period of total amnesia, paranoia and severe anablephobia he'll be ready to work for the good of the Scions. Or maybe someone else - he gets confused. It's the headaches. [PARAGRAPH:1]Alcinus may be upgraded all the way to Archmage level. The Imperial Apparat, however, discourages him from gathering greater power. With an axe, if necessary.

TEXT.English: Alcinus, Imperial Thaumaturge and fourth member of the Dark Council, is one of the - unsteady - foundations of the Scions' magical might. Use him to found the Thaumaturge's Keep and get the Scions' second and third "Palace" mana. The type of mana is chosen by the mad adept and cannot be predicted.[NEWLINE]Alcinus is Immortal, but mad. After being killed he does not always remember or acknowledge his loyalty to the Scions of Patria. There is, however, a method to his madness. A master or Ritual magic, his assistance can greatly increase not only the potency of the ritual, but also the speed with which a city's adepts perform the ritual. Safety and control never being of much concern to the mad mage, his very presence makes a city more vulnerable to ritual attack.

TEXT.English: [LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Part 1: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE]Part 2: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Part 4: In a Bright Land[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:2]In a bright land, in a white city, in a dark room a great emperor sits on his gold throne, plotting. He can feel his adopted people, alive in any significant sense, thriving and free on the face of Erebus. The barbarians to the south and east would fall soon enough, and emissaries were on their way from the "nations" to the north. They would be dealt with. And then west, to the sea, and [BOLD]through[\BOLD] the Sidar. Fools.[PARAGRAPH:1]The silent ones thought they revered Arawn. All they really worship is their idea of that dark god. Not only is he different from what they imagine, he might be more different than they can imagine. God of the Underworld, yes, but only warden of the Dreamlands. What is a god who cedes power and authority at every chance? Who's own chosen realm is a riot of freedom, rotting around him? Life, and Death. Absolute freedom and complete confinement. God of beginnings and endings. Neither light nor dark. The Gray One.[PARAGRAPH:1]He remembered the passage of that oppressive aura, and pressing himself tight against the dark stone. Fear spikes through him and he shifts on his throne. His bodyguards, circling the chamber, stir in turn, every woman's weapon glinting red and silver.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Sidar were right about his color, at least. Brighter than the night, but infinitely deeper. Gray. The emperor shudders, as if bitten by the cold he can never feel. The Hidden Queen had her secrets, but they could be revealed. The Gray One might be unknowable.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Her. How could she be his spawn? Sure compassion... and her brother raging anger. Maybe the twins were just the knowable portions of the God, exiled into the deciphered world.[PARAGRAPH:1]He knew his thoughts went in circles. They always did when he thought of his most successful mission. His Lord had never cloaked him better. Yet it hadn't been enough. Thinking was not the way through. The eyes of memory can never see aright in the dreamlands, only the eyes of dreams.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lights scattered over her black mantle like the stars, and following her through the twisting passages was like spinning up into a night sky that had suddenly abandoned Erebus for the void. Disoriented and lost beyond recovery should she betray him, Rahserat, the fallen Angel of Good Intentions, could only endure as the Hidden Queen guided him down the paths only she knew.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally she halted by a doorway formed of three large bluestones, the horizontal one marked with an eye and a hand. "This is the one," she whispered. "Give me the password."[PARAGRAPH:1]"My Lord bade me tell you only after I stood safe and free within the Underworld."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is the one. The Death God will know if I enter his realm. Give me the password."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm sorry, my lady, but I carry my Lord's trust."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Don't mock me, Rahserat."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Never. But I have been given this," Rahserat produced a small yellow vial. "I will destroy it when I stand in Arawn's kingdom. The knowledge you want to be released to you then."[PARAGRAPH:1]"So." Her whisper was so soft he had to lean forward to catch her words. "And if you do not I will consider your Lord, and you, to have betrayed me."[PARAGRAPH:1]The angel said nothing. He'd been warned against speaking to her more than was absolutely necessary. He merely bowed. She hissed, and gestured at the doorway. He stepped through it.[PARAGRAPH:1]After that it was hard to put things in chronological order. Later he wondered if his own realm drove the Death God insane. Where a human found infinite freedom, bounded only by his own mind and preconceptions, what would the unbounded mind of a god find? It was hard enough being an angel.[PARAGRAPH:1]But he did his master's bidding, working for the downfall of the One and a better world beyond.[PARAGRAPH:1]First he used the vial. Then, cloaked as one of the angels appropriate to this place, Rahserat moved through the dreamlands. He persuaded, he tempted, he cajoled. He ministered to the souls, always playing off their better nature and always guiding them back toward ambition. This kingdom of the most uncaring god was naturally a place of stillness, where the unguided dead lost themselves. And though he did not specifically direct their re-awakened ambitions - that could too easily invite scrutiny - he knew where striving would necessarily lead them: The new center of the dreamlands, the anti-deity Laroth. That Spirit master collected the newly aware dead into an army. An army to challenge the reigning Death God. Even if Laroth was doomed, his plotting weakened Arawn's hold over the underworld and especially his angels. If the grandiose plan succeeded Rahserat didn't know if Laroth would be any better an ally for his Lord than the Hidden Queen. But it would remove a god who stood with the One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat avoided the Forsaken Palace, Arawn's seldom-occupied center of power. Yet as he moved among that god's angels some show of participating in their increasingly disorganized and apathetically pursued work had to be maintained. Thus at times he walked the basalt and chalk halls, trapped for days, sometimes longer, in elaborate games of etiquette and influence. The dead-eyed black-and-white patterned angels that formed the palace guard and inner-administration, called phantoms, were unwaveringly loyal to the Grey One. Every other angel was suspect. Rahserat had to play a careful game both with those of certain loyalty and with those who might be Laroth's minions. But his Lord's cloak, his assumed identity, always held. Or, really, lack of identity. He started thinking of himself as the Other Angel. Never Rahserat. Never the angel he spoke to, or one that angel had just seen or spoken with. Always someone else. The Other Angel.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even when he escaped the Palace a feeling of self-alienation didn't leave him. Mirrors began haunting him. Usually empty, but sometimes they showed Laroth. Even Basium, whose thundering could sometimes be heard throughout the underworld, at least by an angel, would be clever enough to understand. What did Rahserat do so differently from Laroth? Both twisted the spirit or soul out of true, both always using something within the spirit or soul to do so. Laroth did so for personal gain, while Rahserat helped topple empires for his Lord, and thus for all of creation. But still the mirrors haunted. Rather than spinning a dream he could inhabit Rahserat felt he was unraveling himself, weaving a new Rahserat. One who took souls supposedly safe within the underworld and drove them on. Hell, the great machine that was Agares' greatest triumph, now reached here. Thanks to Rahserat. It was better than utter destruction, but the world would pay a great price to withstand the One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even with angelic memory he couldn't know when it happened, on which sortie into the Palace it occurred. But while transversing a black stone gallery above the entrance hall Rahserat felt the arrival of the Death God. There was a pull, or a calling. Maybe it was what mortality felt like? But it was irresistible, and all eyes went to the Twilight Portal.[PARAGRAPH:1]A guard of phantoms assembled along the wide, descending stairway from the great doors. Their black and white ribbons hung limp, stirring only when they turned, as one, to face the Portal. Two were already by the doors and pulling on the great rings, swinging wide the doors and revealing the Grey One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Stern and aloof, he loomed in the open doorway like a thundercloud. Fine clothes, with both tunic and pants of a rich, thick cloth. But everything only in shades of grey. Pale silver from the lining and jet rings on the hands were the only adornments. And, like a cloud, he dimmed light in his presence. The phantoms at the doors prostrated themselves. Uncaring, the Death God passed them and descended the stairway. Each phantom going to one knee as he strode by. A wave of ribbons in absolute hues fooled the eye, blending and seeming still even as they rippled with the sudden motion. So flanked by motionless movement, by black and white mixed to grey, by the bowed heads of servants utterly loyal and completely unacknowledged, Arawn entered his palace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat should have fled when he first felt the god. He had no wish to test his masks against the Grey One himself. But Arawn could never be avoided indefinitely. And Arawn was already walking up the gallery.[PARAGRAPH:1]The illicit angel pressed himself into an alcove carved directly from the basalt. Fighting an urge to run Rahserat went to his knees, bowing toward the walkway, and then went still. The footsteps of the Death God and his retinue were the only sounds, and they were coming closer. Then they were before him, and died away. Hearing nothing, knowing Arawn stood before him, Rahserat looked up.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"Who are [BOLD]you?[\BOLD]"[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Suddenly unable to see, the god's demand hit Rahserat like a hammer blow. Was this how Iaegus fell? The angel felt like he might be crushed, caught between the god's pull and the need to escape. He choked back a damning response and concentrated on his Lord's precept.[PARAGRAPH:1]When Arawn turned his head Rahserat could see again. The god spoke to someone beside him.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"It hardly matters. Give him to your brother. Whatever's necessary should be done."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, Arawn. I will see to what's needed."[PARAGRAPH:1]The god walked on, leaving Rahserat with an angel of female aspect. Pale, with long hair utterly black, and wearing pure white. She looked after the god until that one, never glancing back or even to the side, had turned a corner. Then she beckoned Rahserat with a gesture. "Stand."[PARAGRAPH:1]No, she wasn't an angel. She possessed too strong an aura. An archangel.[PARAGRAPH:1]A pair of phantoms waited at her side, one with a spear and one with chains. "You may go. This one is no threat to me. You," she gestured to Rahserat again. "You will come with me."[PARAGRAPH:1]The phantoms followed their god, and Gyra suddenly took Rahserat's face in her hands, seizing him with her eyes. "I will not give you to my brother. I will not even see you driven from this place. For you have work to do."[PARAGRAPH:1]Her eyes blazed, lit by something Rahserat thought he'd seen before, but had long since forgotten. "You see, little angel, [ITALICS]I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra took him from the Forsaken Palace and to her own places on the edge of the underworld. She showed him many things. Though it was properly in the keeping of her brother, she showed him an unguarded and secret way into Erebus: The Ivory Gate. She showed him better ways to bend others to his will. She could wield compassion like a knife, a knife she gave to him. She took him into her home and introduced him to her daughter, and he though she said nothing he thought he saw a father beyond the daughter: A one-handed man with stars for eyes.[PARAGRAPH:1]And never did she remonstrate with him for his deceptions, for sending more souls on to fallen Spirit master, one who he knew she worked to stop. All of this surprised him. Especially the daughter, Korinna. But nothing shocked him like the false Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]They stood on a cliff somehow high above the dreamlands. "Arawn made this place, to more easily survey his domain. My brother cares for other things and never came here, and Arawn comes here seldom now. But still, we shouldn't linger. I have something to show you, then a place for us to go. Come and see."[PARAGRAPH:1]He stepped to the edge and looked where she pointed. "There," she said. "Use your eyes, angel, and look upon the false new kingdom!"[PARAGRAPH:1]It was subtle, but a part of the dreamland, the inhabited underworld, seemed organized. It flowed like the rest, but some dreams stayed apart, mixing only among each other. Reading the flow for pattern, Rahserat looked for that pattern's source. There  a center. A huge hall, like an ivory vault. Mortals of all sorts at its walls and in the center a man with a mirrored crown. The would-be god, Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra touched his shoulder and Rahserat's gaze was torn from the distance. Then the archangel's pointing finger commanded his attention in a new direction. There he spied another seed of order within the dreamland's chaos. Another pattern. This one was smaller, and even more subtle. Furtive might have been a better word. At its center another hall, empty this time. But there was another throne. And on this throne..."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You look upon the new false kingdom, Rahserat. Now: Come and see."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra took Rahserat's hand, effortlessly lifting him with her as she rose above the cliff. Then, moving them in her own manner across the dreamland, Rahserat suddenly stood before the second throne. And the second Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]The features were the same, and the crown. But rather than empty pits a cloth band of arterial red covered the eyes.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat turned his puzzled face toward the archangel. "Another Laroth?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra nodded. "A false one. Most of the souls you stir come to him. Especially the Patrians. Pelemoc, for example, is already here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But who is he?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"He is what the mirrors show you. Yourself. Even angels build from dreams here. That's why Arawn has taken them from the angels at the palace. And maybe why..." She shook her head, midnight tresses covering her face for a moment, clearly changing her mind about what she'd been about to say. Continuing, she said "And this is your dream. Or nightmare, I don't know. But this is what you thought you might be. Just like Laroth, but of course you'd rather not just feed his power. Here is your own power base. Souls have been gathering here just as they have around Laroth's throne. But the false Laroth, unlike the other, is [ITALICS]completely[\ITALICS] your creature. He holds the souls here in trust. He will commend them to you, to do with as you will. Let them join Laroth, or swear to your god. Or you may keep them for yourself."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is an extravagant power you let him... let me possess. Even if it's far less than Laroth's. You oppose him, why do you aid me?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I told you, angel, I know who you are."[PARAGRAPH:1]She refused to explain what she meant, as always, but made Rahserat and herself visible, then introduced him to the false Laroth. The Other Angel. Just as she'd said, the dream-formed Laroth accepted Rahserat as his Lord without the slightest hesitation. He obeyed Rahserat in everything. Laroth summoned some of the lords of men he'd already gathered, introducing Rahserat as their Emperor. Pelemoc indeed was among them, as was Melante. More, the false Laroth told him, would be with him soon. And there were.[PARAGRAPH:1]The false Laroth could do the work he'd been sent for, and better. He suspected Gyra had a hand in his formation, but that was another subject on which she would not comment. Eventually Rahserat realized he wasn't needed, and should leave. Esus might not want the souls to go to the real Laroth if there were other options. And, if nothing else, they could be sold or traded to the hopeful usurper. His Lord knew the price of everything. Rahserat bade the false Laroth to send him a portion of the souls he snared. His Lord might find an immediate use for them, and they'd act as proof.[PARAGRAPH:1]His Lord was not trusting.[PARAGRAPH:1]Furthermore, Gyra offered him a secret way out of the underworld. The ways of the Hidden Queen were almost impossible to find, and dangerous even then. With his mission fulfilled Rahserat had planned seeking passage from Basium. One way or another. But that choleric archangel might see past his masks just as Arawn had. Gyra's charge was entrance to the underworld, but she knew of a few ways out. The Ivory Gate was one. Finally, most importantly, she had a favor to ask of him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I want you to foster my daughter."[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat was sure he'd come to understand mortals far more since he'd arrived in the underworld. He'd had to act more furtively than ever before. He'd learned fear. He'd been discovered by one who stood to him as he stood to mortals. He'd learned defeat. And he, far older than most mortals could even comprehend, had been subjected to one surprise after another. This was another.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You want me to take Korinna?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes. She can't stay here. Despite my efforts she cannot... grow here. Erebus would be better for her. And she can open the Ivory Gate for you. She will go ahead, and is mortal enough to find it from the other side. It's the sure way."
TEXT.French: [H1]Dans une contrée prospère[\H1][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Chapitre 1 : Dans une contrée prospère, l'Empereur Ressuscité[\LINK][NEWLINE]Chapitre 2 : Dans une contrée prospère, l'Éveillé[PARAGRAPH:2]Dans une contrée prospère, dans une ville blanche, dans une pièce sombre, un grand empereur est assis sur son trône doré, complotant. Il peut sentir son peuple adoptif, vivant d'après toutes les définitions, florissant et libre à la surface d'Erebus. Les barbares au sud et à l'est tomberaient bien assez tôt, et des émissaires étaient en chemin depuis les "nations" au nord. On s'en occuperait. Puis l'ouest, vers la mer, et [BOLD]à travers[\BOLD] les Sidarae. Imbéciles.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les silencieux pensaient qu'ils révéraient Arawn. Tout ce qu'ils vénèrent réellement est leur idée de ce dieu sombre. Il ne se contente pas d'être différent de ce qu'ils imaginent, il pourrait être plus différent que ce qu'ils peuvent imaginer. Dieu de l'Outremonde, certes, mais seulement gardien des Terres du Rêve. Qu'est-ce qu'un dieu qui cède pouvoir et autorité chaque fois qu'il le peut ? Dont le choix du royaume se porte sur un de lutte des libertés, pourrissant autour de lui ? Vie et Mort. Liberté absolue et confinement total. Dieu des débuts et des fins. Ni bon ni mauvais. Le Dieu Gris.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il se souvenait du moment dans cette zone oppressante, et se colla contre la pierre noire. Sentit la menace des lances et remua sur son trône. Ses gardes du corps, encerclèrent la chambre, se plaçant en cercle, chaque arme de ces femmes luisant de rouge et d'argent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les Sidarae avaient au moins vu juste quant à sa couleur. Plus brillante que la nuit, mais infiniment plus profonde. Le Gris. L'Empereur frissonna, comme s'il était mordu par le froid qu'il ne pourrait jamais ressentir. La Reine Cachée avait ses secrets, mais ils pouvaient être révélés. Le Dieu Gris pouvait être impossible à appréhender.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"Je sais qui tu es, même si toi tu ne le sais pas."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Elle. Comment pouvait elle être son engeance ? À coup sûr compatissante... et son frère empli d'une rage bouillonnante. Peut-être que les jumeaux n'étaient que des portions du Dieu que l'on peut appréhender, exilés dans ce monde de compréhension.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il savait que ses pensées tournaient en rond. Elles le faisaient chaque fois qu'il repensait à sa mission la plus fructueuse. Son Seigneur ne l'avait jamais si bien déguisé. Et pourtant ça n'avait pas été suffisant. Y penser n'arrangerait rien. Les yeux de la mémoire ne pouvaient jamais voir juste dans les Terres du Rêve. Seuls le pouvaient les yeux des rêves.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les lumières se dispersèrent sur son manteau noir comme autant d'étoiles, et la suivre dans les chemins tortueux était comme tourner sur soi sous un ciel étoilé qui aurait subitement abandonné Erebus pour le néant. Désorienté et perdu au-delà de ses capacités, elle aurait pu le trahir, lui, Rahserat, l'Ange déchu des Bonnes Intentions, et il ne pouvait que se laisser guider tandis que la Reine Cachée l'emmenait sur des chemins qu'elle seule connaissait.[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle s'arrêta finalement devant un encadrement de porte constitué de trois grosses pierres bleues, dont l'horizontale était marquée par un oeil et une main." "C'est ici," murmura-t-elle. "Donne moi le mot de passe."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mon Seigneur m'a prié de ne te le dire qu'après m'être tenu sain et sauf dans l'Outremonde."[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'est ici. Le Dieu de la Mort le saura si j'entre dans son royaume. Donne moi le mot de passe."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je suis désolé ma Dame, mais je suis la volonté de mon Seigneur."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Ne te moque pas de moi, Rahserat."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Jamais. Mais on m'a donné ceci," et Rahserat sortit une petit fiole jaune. "Je la détruirai quand je me tiendrai dans le royaume d'Arawn. Ce que vous voulez savoir vous sera alors révélé."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Soit." Son murmure était si faible qu'il dût pencher la tête en avant pour saisir ses mots. "Et si tu ne le fais pas, je considèrerai que ton Seigneur et toi m'avez trahie."[PARAGRAPH:1]L'ange ne répondit rien. On l'avait prévenu de ne pas lui parler plus que ce qui était absolument nécessaire. Il s'inclina simplement. Elle siffla et montra l'embrasure. Il la traversa.[PARAGRAPH:1]Après ça, il était difficile de tout remettre dans l'ordre chronologique. Plus tard, il se demanda si son propre royaume n'avait pas rendu fou le Dieu de la Mort. Là où un humain trouvait une liberté infinie, limitée uniquement par ses idées préconçues et son propre esprit, que trouverait l'esprit illimité d'un dieu ? Il était déjà bien assez dur d'être un ange.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mais il réalisa la volonté de son maître, travaillant à la chute du Premier et à un meilleur monde derrière.[PARAGRAPH:1]Il utilisa d'abord la fiole. Puis, déguisé comme les anges adaptés à ce lieu, Rahserat se déplaça dans les Terres du Rêve. Il persuada, il tenta, il cajola. Il s'adressa aux âmes, toujours en usant du meilleur d'elles-mêmes et toujours en les replançant sur le chemin de l'ambition. Ce royaume du dieu le moins attentionné était naturellement un lieu d'immobilisme, où les morts laissés à eux-mêmes se perdent. Et bien qu'il ne guida pas spécifiquement leurs ambitions ressuscitées (ce qui attirerait trop facilement l'attention) il savait où leurs efforts les mèneraient : le nouveau centre des Terres du Rêve, l'anti-dieu Laroth. Ce maître esprit collectait les nouveaux morts conscients en une armée. Une armée pour défier le Dieu de la Mort. Même si Laroth était condamné, sa machination avait affaibli l'emprise d'Arawn sur l'outremonde et particulièrement ses anges. Si ce plan grandiose réussissait, Rahserat ne savait pas si Laroth serait un meilleur allié pour son Seigneur que la Reine Cachée. Mais il éliminerait un dieu de mèche avec le Premier.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat évita le Palais Abandonné, le centre du pouvoir d'Arawn, rarement occupé. Pourtant, tandis qu'il se mouvait parmi les anges de ce dieu, certains montraient des velléités de participation à leur travail de plus en plus désorganisé et apathique qu'ils devaient pousuivre. Ainsi par moments, alors qu'il marchait dans les couloirs de basalte et de craie, il les voyait, piégés depuis des jours, parfois plus, dans des jeux élaborés d'étiquette et d'influence. Les anges aux yeux morts faits de motifs noirs et blancs qui formaient la garde du palais et de l'administration centrale, nommés fantômes, étaient fanatiquement loyaux au Dieu Gris. Tout autre ange était suspect. Rahserat jouait un jeu dangereux, en jouant à la fois avec ceux à la loyauté indéflectible et avec ceux qui pourraient être les pions de Laroth. Mais la couverture de son Seigneur, son identité avouée, a tenu bon. Ou plutôt son manque d'identité. Il commença à penser à lui comme l'Autre Ange. Jamais Rahserat. Jamais l'ange à qui il parlait, ou l'ange qu'il venait de voir ou à qui il venait de parler. Toujours quelqu'un d'autre. L'Autre Ange.[PARAGRAPH:1]Même après s'être échappé du Palais, un sentiment d'auto-aliénation ne le quitta pas. Les Miroirs commencèrent à le hanter. Généralement vides, mais parfois ils lui montraient Laroth. Même Basium, dont le tonnerre pouvait être parfois entendu au travers de l'outremonde, au moins par un ange, serait assez malin pour comprendre. Qu'est-ce que Rahserath avait fait de si différent par rapport à Laroth ? Les deux avaient détourné les ésprits ou les âmes de la vérité, et les deux utilisaient quelque chose à l'intérieur de l'eprit ou de l'âme pour y parvenir. Laroth l'avait fait pour son compte, tandis que Rahserat aidait à renverser des empires pour son Seigneur, et ainsi pour Création toute entière. Et pourtant les miroirs le hantaient. Plutôt que de tournoyer dans un rêve qu'il pourrait habiter, Rahserat sentit qu'il se démêlait, tissant un nouveau Rahserat. Celui qui prenait des âmes prétendument en sécurité au sein de l'outremonde et les guidait. L'enfer, la grande machine qui était le plus grand triomphe d'Agares, était arrivée. Grâce à Rahserat. C'était mieux qu'une destruction complète, mais le monde aurait à payer un prix exorbitant pour s'opposer au Premier.[PARAGRAPH:1]Même avec sa mémoire angélique il ne savait quand c'était arrivé, ni à quelle porte du Palais. Mais tandis qu'il parcourait une gallerie de pierre noire au-dessus de l'entrée, Rahserat ressentit l'arrivée du Dieu de la Mort. C'était un tiraillement, ou un appel. Peut-être la mortalité ressemblait-elle à ça ? Mais c'était irrésistible, et tous les yeux se tournèrent vers le Portail du Crépuscule. Une garde de fantômes s'assembla le long du large escalier qui descendait des grandes portes. Leurs rubans noir et blanc pendaient mollement, ne bougeant que lorsqu'ils se tournèrent, comme un seul, pour faire face au Portail. Deux d'entre eux étaient déjà aux portes en train de tirer sur les grands anneaux, ouvrant grand les portes et révélant le Dieu Gris.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sévère et distant, il se dessina dans l'encadrement de la porte comme un nuage orageux. Il portait de beaux vêtements, avec à la fois une tunique et un pantalon d'une étoffe riche et épaisse. Mais tout apparaissait en nuances de gris. De l'argent pâle aux doublures, et des anneaux de jais aux poignets étaient ses seules parures. Et tel un nuage il assombrissait la lumière de sa présence. Les fantômes aux portes se prosternèrent. Sans y prêter attention, le Dieu de la Mort passa à leur hauteur et descendit les escaliers. Chaque fantôme s'agenouillait à son passage. Un flot de rubans trompaient les yeux de leurs teintes absolues, s'assemblant et semblant statiques alors même qu'ils ondoyaient avec le mouvement soudain. C'est ainsi que, entouré par des mouvements 'immobiles', par du noir et du blanc mélangés au gris, par les têtes baissées de serviteurs absolument loyaux et totalement non reconnus, Arawn pénétra dans son Palais.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat aurait dû fuir dès l'instant où il avait senti le dieu. Il n'avait pas envie de mettre son déguisement à l'épreuve fauce au Dieu Gris lui-même. Mais Arawn ne pourrait pas être évité indéfiniment. Et Arawn arpentait déjà la gallerie.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'ange intrus se précipita dans une alcôve creusée directement dans le basalte. Luttant contre l'envie de s'enfuir, Rahserat s'agenouilla, baissant la tête en direction du passage, et s'immobilisa. Les pas du Dieu de la Mort et de son entourage étaient les seuls sons, et ils s'approchaient. Puis ils passèrent devant lui, et moururent. N'entendant rien, sachant qu'Arawn se tenait devant lui, Rahserat leva les yeux.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"Qui es-[BOLD]tu ?[\BOLD]"[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Soudainement incapable de voir, Rahserat encaissa la demande du dieu comme un coup de marteau. Était-ce ce qu'avait ressenti Iaegus ? L'ange eut l'impression qu'il pouvait être broyé, pris entre l'attraction du dieu et le besoin de s'enfuir. Il retint une réponse malheureuse et se concentra sur les enseignements de son Seigneur.[PARAGRAPH:1]Quand Arawn tourna la tête, Rahserat recouvra la vue. Le dieu parla à quelqu'un derrière lui.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"Ça n'a pas d'importance. Donne le à ton frère. Et que tout ce qui est nécessaire soit fait."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui, Arawn. Je me renseignerai sur ce qui est nécessaire."[PARAGRAPH:1]Arawn recommenca à marcher, laissa Rahserat avec un ange d'aspect féminin. Pâle, avec de longs cheveux totalement noirs, et habillée de blanc immaculé. Elle regarda le dieu jusqu'à ce que ce dernier, sans jeter un regard en arrière ou même sur les côtés, tourne à un coin. Puis elle fit un signe de la main à l'attention de Rahserat. "Lève-toi."[PARAGRAPH:1]Non, elle n'était pas un ange. Son aura était trop puissante. Un archange.[PARAGRAPH:1]Deux fantômes attendaient à ses côtés, l'un équipé d'un lance et l'autre de chaînes. "Vous pouvez nous laisser. Il ne représente pas une menace pour moi. Toi," elle à nouveau signe à Rahserat. "Tu viens avec moi."[PARAGRAPH:1]Les fantômes suivirent leur dieu, et Gyra prit soudainement le visage de Rahserat dans ses mains, le vrillant du regard. "Je ne te donnerai pas à mon frère. Je ne te ferai même pas sortir d'ici. Car tu as un travail à accomplir."[PARAGRAPH:1]Ses yeux flamboyèrent, illuminés par quelque chose que Rahserat pensait avoir déjà vu auparavant, mais avait oublié depuis longtemps. "Tu vois, petit ange, [ITALICS]je sais qui tu es, même si toi tu ne le sais pas."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra le fit sortir du Palais Abandonné et l'amena dans ses terres aux confins de l'outremonde. Elle lui montra maintes choses. Même s'il était sous la surveillance de son frère, elle lui montra un passage secret non gardé pour entrer en Erebus : la Porte d'Ivoire. Elle lui montra de meilleures techniques pour soumettre les autres à sa volonté. Elle pouvait user de compassion comme d'un couteau, un couteau dont elle lui fit don. Elle l'amena chez elle et le présenta à sa fille, et même si elle ne dit rien, il crut deviner un père derrière la fille : un homme manchot avec des étoiles à la place des yeux.[PARAGRAPH:1]Et jamais elle ne lui reprocha ses trahisons, d'avoir envoyé plus d'âmes au maître Esprit, celui qu'elle cherchait à arrêter. Tout ceci le surprit. Particulièrement la fille, Korinna. Mais rien ne le choqua plus que le faux Laroth. Ils se tenaient sur une falaise assez haute au-dessus des terres du rêve. "Arawn a construit cet endroit pour pouvoir surveiller son domaine plus aisément. Mon frère s'occupe d'autres choses et ne vient jamais ici, et Arawn y vient maintenant rarement. Mais nous ne devrions pas traîner. Je dois te montrer quelque chose, puis un endroit où nous devons aller. Approche et observe."[PARAGRAPH:1]Il s'approcha du bord et regarda dans la direction qu'elle pointait. "Là," dit-elle. "Utilise tes yeux, ange, et observe le faux nouveau royaume !"[PARAGRAPH:1]C'était subtil, mais une portion des terres du rêve, l'outremonde inhabité, semblait organisé. Ça se mouvait, comme le reste, mais certains rêves restaient isolés, ne se mélangeant qu'entre eux. Discernant un schéma derrière les courants, Rahserat remonta vers la source de ce schéma. Là : un centre. Un énorme hall, comme une arche d'ivoire. Des mortels de toutes sortes sur les murs et au centre un homme avec une couronne de miroirs. Le simili-dieu, Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra toucha son épaule et le regard de Rahserat redevint proche. Puis le doigt pointé de l'archange attira son attention dans une nouvelle direction. Il y aperçut une nouvelle graine d'ordre au sein du chaos des terres du rêve. Un aurte schéma. Celui-là était plus petit, et encore plus subtil. Furtif aurait été plus adapté. Au centre, un autre hall, vide celui-là. Mais il y avait un autre trône. Et sur ce trône..."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Tu observes là le nouveau faux royaume, Rahserat. Maintenant, approche et observe."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra prit la main de Rahserat, et le souleva sans effort tandis qu'elle s'élevait au-dessus de la falaise. Puis, les déplaçant selon son bon vouloir au-dessus des terres du rêve, Rahserat se retrouva soudainement devant le second trône. Et le second Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les traits étaient les mêmes, ainsi que la couronne. Mais à la place des orbites vides, un bandeau de tissu d'un rouge veineux couvrait les yeux.[PARAGRAPH:1]Perplexe, Rahserat se tourna vers l'archange. "Un autre Laroth ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra acquiesca. "Un faux. La plupart des âmes que tu affectes vont à lui. Particulièrement les Patriens. Pelemoc, par exemple, est déjà là."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Mais qui est-il ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Il est ce que les miroirs te montrent. Toi. Même les anges se construisent grâce aux rêves ici. C'est pourquoi Arawn les a otés des anges du palais. Et probablement pourquoi..." Elle secoua la tête, ses cheveux noirs comme la nuit couvrant son visage pendant un instant, changeant clairement d'avis à propos de ce qu'elle s'apprêtait à lui dire. Poursuivant, elle dit "Et ceci est ton rêve. Ou ton cauchemar, je ne sais pas. Mais ceci est ce que tu crois pouvoir être. De même que Laroth, mais bien sûr tu ferais mieux de ne pas juste renforcer son pouvoir. Ceci est ta propre source de puissance. Les âmes se sont rassemblées ici comme elles le font autour du trône de Laroth. Mais le faux Laroth, à l'inverse de l'autre, est [ITALICS]totalement[\ITALICS] ta créature. Il contrôle les âmes présentes par la confiance. Il les commandera, pour agir selon ton bon plaisir. Laisse les rejoindre Laroth, ou se rallier à ton dieu. Ou tu peux les conserver pour toi-même."[PARAGRAPH:1]"C'est un pouvoir énorme que tu le laisses... me laisses posséder. Même s'il est bien moindre que celui de Laroth. Tu le combats, pourquoi m'aider ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je te l'ai dit, ange, je sais qui tu es."[PARAGRAPH:1]Elle refusa de s'expliquer, comme toujours, mais se rendit visible de même que Rahserat, puis le présenta au faux Laroth. L'Autre Ange. Comme elle l'avait dit, le Laroth issu des rêves accepta Rahserat comme son Seigneur sans la moindre hésitation. Il obéit à tout ordre de Rahserat. Laroth invoqua certains des seigneurs des hommes qu'il avait déjà récoltés, et présenta Rahserat comme leur Empereur. Pelemoc était effectivement parmi eux, tout comme Melante. De plus, le faux Laroth lui parlerait, serait bientôt avec lui. Et ils le furent. Le faux Laroth pouvait réaliser le travail qu'on lui assignait, et plus encore. Il suspecta Gyra d'avoir pris part à sa formation, mais c'était un autre sujet qu'elle refusait d'aborder. Finalement, Rahserat réalisa que sa présence n'était pas nécessaire, et qu'il devrait partir. Esus pourrait ne pas vouloir que les âmes aillent au vrai Laroth s'il existait une autre option. Et, à défaut, elles pourraient être vendues ou échangées au profit de l'usurpateur plein d'espoir. Son Seigneur connaissait le prix de chaque chose. Rahserat demanda au faux Laroth de lui donner une partie des âmes qu'il avait piégées. Son Seigneur pourrait leur trouver une utilité immédiate, et elles pourraient faire office de preuve.[PARAGRAPH:1]Son Seigneur n'était pas confiant.[PARAGRAPH:1]en outre, Gyra lui offrit un échappatoire secret de l'outremonde. Les voies de la Reine Cachée étaient presque impossible à trouver, et restaient de toutes les façons dangereuses. Sa mission remplie, Rahserat pensait ensuite rechercher un passage vers Basium. D'une manière ou d'une autre. Mais cet archange colérique pourrait perçer ses masques à jour comme Arawn l'avait fait. Le périmètre de Gyra était l'accès à l'outremonde, mais elle connaissait quelques sorties. La Porte d'Ivoire en était une. Enfin, et c'était le plus important, elle avait une faveur à lui demander.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Je veux que tu adoptes ma fille."[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat était sûr de pouvoir bien mieux comprendre les mortels depuis qu'il était arrivé dans l'outremonde. Il avait dû agir bien plus discrètement qu'avant. Il avait appris la peur. Il avait été découvert par quelqu'un qui le considérait comme il considérait les mortels. Il avait appris la défaite. Et lui, bien plus vieux que ce que la plupart des mortels pourraient imaginer, avait été de surprise en surprise. Ceci en était une autre.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Vous voulez que j'emmène Korinna ?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Oui. Elle ne peut pas rester ici. Malgré mes efforts elle ne peut pas... grandir ici. Erebus devrait être mieux pour elle. Et elle peut ouvrir la Porte d'Ivoire pour toi. Elle passera devant, et est assez mortelle pour la trouver depuis l'autre côté. C'est la solution la plus sûre."[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Chapitre 3 : Dans une contrée prospère, Korinna[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Chapitre 4 : Dans une contrée prospère, la Cathédrale de la Renaissance[\LINK]
TEXT.German: [LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_1]Part 1: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE]Part 2: In a Bright Land[NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_3]Part 3: In a Bright Land[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=LORE_BRIGHT_LAND_4]Part 4: In a Bright Land[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:2]In a bright land, in a white city, in a dark room a great emperor sits on his gold throne, plotting. He can feel his adopted people, alive in any significant sense, thriving and free on the face of Erebus. The barbarians to the south and east would fall soon enough, and emissaries were on their way from the "nations" to the north. They would be dealt with. And then west, to the sea, and [BOLD]through[\BOLD] the Sidar. Fools.[PARAGRAPH:1]The silent ones thought they revered Arawn. All they really worship is their idea of that dark god. Not only is he different from what they imagine, he might be more different than they can imagine. God of the Underworld, yes, but only warden of the Dreamlands. What is a god who cedes power and authority at every chance? Who's own chosen realm is a riot of freedom, rotting around him? Life, and Death. Absolute freedom and complete confinement. God of beginnings and endings. Neither light nor dark. The Gray One.[PARAGRAPH:1]He remembered the passage of that oppressive aura, and pressing himself tight against the dark stone. Fear spikes through him and he shifts on his throne. His bodyguards, circling the chamber, stir in turn, every woman's weapon glinting red and silver.[PARAGRAPH:1]The Sidar were right about his color, at least. Brighter than the night, but infinitely deeper. Gray. The emperor shudders, as if bitten by the cold he can never feel. The Hidden Queen had her secrets, but they could be revealed. The Gray One might be unknowable.[PARAGRAPH:1]ITALICS]"I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Her. How could she be his spawn? Sure compassion... and her brother raging anger. Maybe the twins were just the knowable portions of the God, exiled into the deciphered world.[PARAGRAPH:1]He knew his thoughts went in circles. They always did when he thought of his most successful mission. His Lord had never cloaked him better. Yet it hadn't been enough. Thinking was not the way through. The eyes of memory can never see aright in the dreamlands, only the eyes of dreams.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lights scattered over her black mantle like the stars, and following her through the twisting passages was like spinning up into a night sky that had suddenly abandoned Erebus for the void. Disoriented and lost beyond recovery should she betray him, Rahserat, the fallen Angel of Good Intentions, could only endure as the Hidden Queen guided him down the paths only she knew.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally she halted by a doorway formed of three large bluestones, the horizontal one marked with an eye and a hand. "This is the one," she whispered. "Give me the password."[PARAGRAPH:1]"My Lord bade me tell you only after I stood safe and free within the Underworld."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is the one. The Death God will know if I enter his realm. Give me the password."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I'm sorry, my lady, but I carry my Lord's trust."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Don't mock me, Rahserat."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Never. But I have been given this," Rahserat produced a small yellow vial. "I will destroy it when I stand in Arawn's kingdom. The knowledge you want to be released to you then."[PARAGRAPH:1]"So." Her whisper was so soft he had to lean forward to catch her words. "And if you do not I will consider your Lord, and you, to have betrayed me."[PARAGRAPH:1]The angel said nothing. He'd been warned against speaking to her more than was absolutely necessary. He merely bowed. She hissed, and gestured at the doorway. He stepped through it.[PARAGRAPH:1]After that it was hard to put things in chronological order. Later he wondered if his own realm drove the Death God insane. Where a human found infinite freedom, bounded only by his own mind and preconceptions, what would the unbounded mind of a god find? It was hard enough being an angel.[PARAGRAPH:1]But he did his master's bidding, working for the downfall of the One and a better world beyond.[PARAGRAPH:1]First he used the vial. Then, cloaked as one of the angels appropriate to this place, Rahserat moved through the dreamlands. He persuaded, he tempted, he cajoled. He ministered to the souls, always playing off their better nature and always guiding them back toward ambition. This kingdom of the most uncaring god was naturally a place of stillness, where the unguided dead lost themselves. And though he did not specifically direct their re-awakened ambitions - that could too easily invite scrutiny - he knew where striving would necessarily lead them: The new center of the dreamlands, the anti-deity Laroth. That Spirit master collected the newly aware dead into an army. An army to challenge the reigning Death God. Even if Laroth was doomed, his plotting weakened Arawn's hold over the underworld and especially his angels. If the grandiose plan succeeded Rahserat didn't know if Laroth would be any better an ally for his Lord than the Hidden Queen. But it would remove a god who stood with the One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat avoided the Forsaken Palace, Arawn's seldom-occupied center of power. Yet as he moved among that god's angels some show of participating in their increasingly disorganized and apathetically pursued work had to be maintained. Thus at times he walked the basalt and chalk halls, trapped for days, sometimes longer, in elaborate games of etiquette and influence. The dead-eyed black-and-white patterned angels that formed the palace guard and inner-administration, called phantoms, were unwaveringly loyal to the Grey One. Every other angel was suspect. Rahserat had to play a careful game both with those of certain loyalty and with those who might be Laroth's minions. But his Lord's cloak, his assumed identity, always held. Or, really, lack of identity. He started thinking of himself as the Other Angel. Never Rahserat. Never the angel he spoke to, or one that angel had just seen or spoken with. Always someone else. The Other Angel.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even when he escaped the Palace a feeling of self-alienation didn't leave him. Mirrors began haunting him. Usually empty, but sometimes they showed Laroth. Even Basium, whose thundering could sometimes be heard throughout the underworld, at least by an angel, would be clever enough to understand. What did Rahserat do so differently from Laroth? Both twisted the spirit or soul out of true, both always using something within the spirit or soul to do so. Laroth did so for personal gain, while Rahserat helped topple empires for his Lord, and thus for all of creation. But still the mirrors haunted. Rather than spinning a dream he could inhabit Rahserat felt he was unraveling himself, weaving a new Rahserat. One who took souls supposedly safe within the underworld and drove them on. Hell, the great machine that was Agares' greatest triumph, now reached here. Thanks to Rahserat. It was better than utter destruction, but the world would pay a great price to withstand the One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Even with angelic memory he couldn't know when it happened, on which sortie into the Palace it occurred. But while transversing a black stone gallery above the entrance hall Rahserat felt the arrival of the Death God. There was a pull, or a calling. Maybe it was what mortality felt like? But it was irresistible, and all eyes went to the Twilight Portal.[PARAGRAPH:1]A guard of phantoms assembled along the wide, descending stairway from the great doors. Their black and white ribbons hung limp, stirring only when they turned, as one, to face the Portal. Two were already by the doors and pulling on the great rings, swinging wide the doors and revealing the Grey One.[PARAGRAPH:1]Stern and aloof, he loomed in the open doorway like a thundercloud. Fine clothes, with both tunic and pants of a rich, thick cloth. But everything only in shades of grey. Pale silver from the lining and jet rings on the hands were the only adornments. And, like a cloud, he dimmed light in his presence. The phantoms at the doors prostrated themselves. Uncaring, the Death God passed them and descended the stairway. Each phantom going to one knee as he strode by. A wave of ribbons in absolute hues fooled the eye, blending and seeming still even as they rippled with the sudden motion. So flanked by motionless movement, by black and white mixed to grey, by the bowed heads of servants utterly loyal and completely unacknowledged, Arawn entered his palace.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat should have fled when he first felt the god. He had no wish to test his masks against the Grey One himself. But Arawn could never be avoided indefinitely. And Arawn was already walking up the gallery.[PARAGRAPH:1]The illicit angel pressed himself into an alcove carved directly from the basalt. Fighting an urge to run Rahserat went to his knees, bowing toward the walkway, and then went still. The footsteps of the Death God and his retinue were the only sounds, and they were coming closer. Then they were before him, and died away. Hearing nothing, knowing Arawn stood before him, Rahserat looked up.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"Who are [BOLD]you?[\BOLD]"[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Suddenly unable to see, the god's demand hit Rahserat like a hammer blow. Was this how Iaegus fell? The angel felt like he might be crushed, caught between the god's pull and the need to escape. He choked back a damning response and concentrated on his Lord's precept.[PARAGRAPH:1]When Arawn turned his head Rahserat could see again. The god spoke to someone beside him.[PARAGRAPH:1][ITALICS]"It hardly matters. Give him to your brother. Whatever's necessary should be done."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, Arawn. I will see to what's needed."[PARAGRAPH:1]The god walked on, leaving Rahserat with an angel of female aspect. Pale, with long hair utterly black, and wearing pure white. She looked after the god until that one, never glancing back or even to the side, had turned a corner. Then she beckoned Rahserat with a gesture. "Stand."[PARAGRAPH:1]No, she wasn't an angel. She possessed too strong an aura. An archangel.[PARAGRAPH:1]A pair of phantoms waited at her side, one with a spear and one with chains. "You may go. This one is no threat to me. You," she gestured to Rahserat again. "You will come with me."[PARAGRAPH:1]The phantoms followed their god, and Gyra suddenly took Rahserat's face in her hands, seizing him with her eyes. "I will not give you to my brother. I will not even see you driven from this place. For you have work to do."[PARAGRAPH:1]Her eyes blazed, lit by something Rahserat thought he'd seen before, but had long since forgotten. "You see, little angel, [ITALICS]I know who you are, though you do not."[\ITALICS][PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra took him from the Forsaken Palace and to her own places on the edge of the underworld. She showed him many things. Though it was properly in the keeping of her brother, she showed him an unguarded and secret way into Erebus: The Ivory Gate. She showed him better ways to bend others to his will. She could wield compassion like a knife, a knife she gave to him. She took him into her home and introduced him to her daughter, and he though she said nothing he thought he saw a father beyond the daughter: A one-handed man with stars for eyes.[PARAGRAPH:1]And never did she remonstrate with him for his deceptions, for sending more souls on to fallen Spirit master, one who he knew she worked to stop. All of this surprised him. Especially the daughter, Korinna. But nothing shocked him like the false Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]They stood on a cliff somehow high above the dreamlands. "Arawn made this place, to more easily survey his domain. My brother cares for other things and never came here, and Arawn comes here seldom now. But still, we shouldn't linger. I have something to show you, then a place for us to go. Come and see."[PARAGRAPH:1]He stepped to the edge and looked where she pointed. "There," she said. "Use your eyes, angel, and look upon the false new kingdom!"[PARAGRAPH:1]It was subtle, but a part of the dreamland, the inhabited underworld, seemed organized. It flowed like the rest, but some dreams stayed apart, mixing only among each other. Reading the flow for pattern, Rahserat looked for that pattern's source. There  a center. A huge hall, like an ivory vault. Mortals of all sorts at its walls and in the center a man with a mirrored crown. The would-be god, Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra touched his shoulder and Rahserat's gaze was torn from the distance. Then the archangel's pointing finger commanded his attention in a new direction. There he spied another seed of order within the dreamland's chaos. Another pattern. This one was smaller, and even more subtle. Furtive might have been a better word. At its center another hall, empty this time. But there was another throne. And on this throne..."[PARAGRAPH:1]"You look upon the new false kingdom, Rahserat. Now: Come and see."[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra took Rahserat's hand, effortlessly lifting him with her as she rose above the cliff. Then, moving them in her own manner across the dreamland, Rahserat suddenly stood before the second throne. And the second Laroth.[PARAGRAPH:1]The features were the same, and the crown. But rather than empty pits a cloth band of arterial red covered the eyes.[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat turned his puzzled face toward the archangel. "Another Laroth?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Gyra nodded. "A false one. Most of the souls you stir come to him. Especially the Patrians. Pelemoc, for example, is already here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But who is he?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"He is what the mirrors show you. Yourself. Even angels build from dreams here. That's why Arawn has taken them from the angels at the palace. And maybe why..." She shook her head, midnight tresses covering her face for a moment, clearly changing her mind about what she'd been about to say. Continuing, she said "And this is your dream. Or nightmare, I don't know. But this is what you thought you might be. Just like Laroth, but of course you'd rather not just feed his power. Here is your own power base. Souls have been gathering here just as they have around Laroth's throne. But the false Laroth, unlike the other, is [ITALICS]completely[\ITALICS] your creature. He holds the souls here in trust. He will commend them to you, to do with as you will. Let them join Laroth, or swear to your god. Or you may keep them for yourself."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is an extravagant power you let him... let me possess. Even if it's far less than Laroth's. You oppose him, why do you aid me?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I told you, angel, I know who you are."[PARAGRAPH:1]She refused to explain what she meant, as always, but made Rahserat and herself visible, then introduced him to the false Laroth. The Other Angel. Just as she'd said, the dream-formed Laroth accepted Rahserat as his Lord without the slightest hesitation. He obeyed Rahserat in everything. Laroth summoned some of the lords of men he'd already gathered, introducing Rahserat as their Emperor. Pelemoc indeed was among them, as was Melante. More, the false Laroth told him, would be with him soon. And there were.[PARAGRAPH:1]The false Laroth could do the work he'd been sent for, and better. He suspected Gyra had a hand in his formation, but that was another subject on which she would not comment. Eventually Rahserat realized he wasn't needed, and should leave. Esus might not want the souls to go to the real Laroth if there were other options. And, if nothing else, they could be sold or traded to the hopeful usurper. His Lord knew the price of everything. Rahserat bade the false Laroth to send him a portion of the souls he snared. His Lord might find an immediate use for them, and they'd act as proof.[PARAGRAPH:1]His Lord was not trusting.[PARAGRAPH:1]Furthermore, Gyra offered him a secret way out of the underworld. The ways of the Hidden Queen were almost impossible to find, and dangerous even then. With his mission fulfilled Rahserat had planned seeking passage from Basium. One way or another. But that choleric archangel might see past his masks just as Arawn had. Gyra's charge was entrance to the underworld, but she knew of a few ways out. The Ivory Gate was one. Finally, most importantly, she had a favor to ask of him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I want you to foster my daughter."[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat was sure he'd come to understand mortals far more since he'd arrived in the underworld. He'd had to act more furtively than ever before. He'd learned fear. He'd been discovered by one who stood to him as he stood to mortals. He'd learned defeat. And he, far older than most mortals could even comprehend, had been subjected to one surprise after another. This was another.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You want me to take Korinna?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes. She can't stay here. Despite my efforts she cannot... grow here. Erebus would be better for her. And she can open the Ivory Gate for you. She will go ahead, and is mortal enough to find it from the other side. It's the sure way."

Most of the souls you stir come to him. Especially the Patrians. Pelemoc, for example, is already here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"But who is he?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"He is what the mirrors show you. Yourself. Even angels build from dreams here. That's why Arawn has taken them from the angels at the palace. And maybe why..." She shook her head, midnight tresses covering her face for a moment, clearly changing her mind about what she'd been about to say. Continuing, she said "And this is your dream. Or nightmare, I don't know. But this is what you thought you might be. Just like Laroth, but of course you'd rather not just feed his power. Here is your own power base. He will commend them to you, to do with as you will. Let them join Laroth, or swear to your god. Or you may keep them for yourself."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is an extravagant power you let him... let me possess. Even if it's far less than Laroth's. Laroth summoned some of the lords of men he'd already gathered, introducing Rahserat as their Emperor. Pelemoc indeed was among them, as was Melante. More, the false Laroth told him, would be with him soon. And there were.[PARAGRAPH:1]The false Laroth could do the work he'd been sent for, and better. He suspected Gyra had a hand in his formation, but that was another subject on which she would not comment. Eventually Rahserat realized he wasn't needed, and should leave. Esus might not want the souls to go to the real Laroth if there were other options. And, if nothing else, they could be sold or traded to the hopeful usurper. His Lord knew the price of everything. Rahserat bade the false Laroth to send him a portion of the souls he snared. His Lord might find an immediate use for them, and they'd act as proof.[PARAGRAPH:1]His Lord was not trusting.[PARAGRAPH:1]Furthermore, Gyra offered him a secret way out of the underworld. The ways of the Hidden Queen were almost impossible to find, and dangerous even then. With his mission fulfilled Rahserat had planned seeking passage from Basium. One way or another. But that choleric archangel might see past his masks just as Arawn had. Gyra's charge was entrance to the underworld, but she knew of a few ways out. The Ivory Gate was one. Finally, most importantly, she had a favor to ask of him.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I want you to foster my daughter."[PARAGRAPH:1]Rahserat was sure he'd come to understand mortals far more since he'd arrived in the underworld. He'd had to act more furtively than ever before. He'd learned fear. He'd been discovered by one who stood to him as he stood to mortals. He'd learned defeat. And he, far older than most mortals could even comprehend, had been subjected to one surprise after another. This was another.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You want me to take Korinna?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes.
